801997: No more talking, launch the assault
802002: Water in the hull! The overloaded ship could only go so far with this many supplies in its belly: a series of strong waves sends the crates churning and the boat's stomach soon explodes. Cracks pierce the hull where the cargo hit it, and trickles of water pop one after the other in the storage space.
802003: Use the electric water pump to allow proper repairs
802004: Improvise a water pump to allow immediate repairs
802005: Seal the damaged section and repair it at the next harbour
802006: Specific solutions for specific situations: your preparation was on point. The electric pump roars and swallows water much faster that it can infiltrate the ship, allowing the sailors to repair the damage with ease.
802007: Your crew's craftiness has a solution for everything. Using communication tubes as the pump's body and spare metal sheets as paddles, the sailors manage to assemble what could pass for a proper water pump. A good dozen of men is needed to make it work, but they buy enough time for proper repairs.
802008: This joke of a pump looks like it came from the Dark Ages. As the sailors battle to have their own idea of a pump prevail over the others, they assemble a monster that does nothing more than blow bubbles. One of the cracks bursts in a spray of water that silences the machine and starts flooding the hull.
802010: Seal the overflowing section, regardless of what or who might still be inside
802011: Make a decision, who knows what happens if you don't!
802012: The ship rises over the water, but at what cost? Sailors watch their supplies drift away from the vessel, their hearts lingering after the lost items until the officers remind them of the emergency of repairs.
802013: There's nothing to be done. The ship slowly sinks, pulled into the water with each new fracture in its hull. Cargo and crew are washed by the leakage and the ship vomits their remains when it crashes on the shore. The survivors contemplate the wreckage in despair before trying to put the ship back in shape.
802014: Cargo and crew are set to drown in the leakage. The sailors close the hull's doors on their comrades, hushing their screams. However, there is no avoiding reopening the hull when time comes for repairs: the water flows out, carrying bodies transfixed in expressions of suffocation, terror, and betrayal.
802015: The drown cargo cannot be salvaged. When the ship finally finds a harbour, its hull is so low under the waterline your crew fears the boat will sink. Although such fears are unfounded, the leakage drowned a good part of their stored food, and the repairs feel like they should have be done much earlier.
802016: Throw supplies overboard to try and bring the crack over the waterline
802021: These hoodlums are asking for it. To each harbour its own ill-famed tavern, and this one is no exception. While your crew enjoys a beer at the counter, the tavern's door slams open, the bartender stiffens and the volume of conversations dwindles: the newcomers are regulars of the bad kind. One of the scruffy men elbows your doctor and gasps as the alcohol splashes on his unkempt clothes. He immediately grabs your sailor by the collar and demands an apology.
802022: They want to fight? Let them come!
802023: Offer them a drink to ease the tension
802024: This is a waste of time, simply apologize
802025: Your crew crushes them. The collar-grabbed doctor slaps away the hand of the hoodlum, seizes his sleeve and pulls him above his shoulder, sending him to crash into a table. With a roar, the other thugs pounce on your sailors who greet them with jabs to the chin and sternum, downing the attackers with no more than two hits per man - the seconds for the pleasure of good fighting form. The tavern applauds the action and the bartender offers a round to celebrate the deserved beating.
802026: The crew overestimated themselves. As he calls for the other sailors to help, the doctor gets his head smashed into the counter. His crewmates scream for revenge and look like toddlers agitating their little arms to try and hit the big bad guys. The thugs are not in the mood to play along, and one of them stabs a bawling sailor in the liver to make them shut up. They slowly die as the thugs depart, leaving the tavern in a stupor.
802027: The language of alcohol is universal. The thugs take you up on your offer and eye the sailors' purses as they pass the money around to pay for the beers. As the first round arrives, one of the hoodlums speaks up and announces that they will have a drinking contest with the crew. The idea is one-sided and weirdly different from their previous aggressive attitude.
802028: Bribing them with alcohol doesn't seem to work. Your crew invites the men to sit and share a beer, on them, to try and bring the tension down. The thug doesn't let go of the doctor and points at the aligned liquors behind the bartender. A glass of all of these, he says, and a bottle of your best whatever. That's way more than they can drink and way more than your sailors can afford.
802029: Show them the drinking ability of seafarers
802030: Drug their drinks to avoid the confrontation
802031: They call that catpiss strong? There's no question regarding who wins the drinking contest: your crew is still standing and enjoying the beers long after the thugs have hit the ground, curled into whatever their stomach rejected. The pungent smell of vomit and cheap ale does not deter the sailors, who casually finish their steins, pay for them, and drag the hoodlums to the closest man of law.
802032: What kind of liquid fire do they make this with? The crew is used to strong drinks and exotic ales, but the tavern's special mixture of bourbon, sugar and Ricard is way past what they can handle. The thugs are accustomed to this local horror and barely wobble while your sailors pass out one after the other. When they wake up, obviously, their purses are missing.
802033: War anaesthetics are remarkably useful against small-time thugs. After a few rounds spent boasting their virile resistance to any kind of liquor, the crew notices the drop in attention of their opponents and their doctor seizes the opportunity, lacing the incoming mugs with just the right dosage of chloroform. The snoring hoodlums are delivered to the local authorities, who enjoy the unexpected present.
802034: The dosage doesn't put the thugs to sleep: it kills them. The doctor sidles among the thugs, lacing their drinks and snickering in expectation. Soon the effects appear: the gang shows drowsiness, then nausea, loses control of their movements and tumbles against the counter, their faces taking on a waxy yellow color. The crew can do nothing as the hoodlums break into seizures and foam at the mouth. They win the drinking contest by default, murderers of their opponents.
802035: If it's a fight they want, they'll get one
802037: The crew is humiliated. They empty their purses trying to pay for the excessive demands of the thugs. Ale. Stew. Liquors. Meats. When sunrise pushes the hoodlums to leave the tavern, the sailors are stuck with cooking, dishwashing and dust-wiping until the bartender considers their debt paid.
802038: Your sailors apologize through gritted teeth. Pleased by their groveling, the thugs do not pester them anymore, yet the heavy stares of the other clients push your crew to leave the tavern. Next time, they will show them. Next time.
802041: Clear skies, calm seas, and mutiny brewing among your sailors. The strain of the expedition, the rationing of supplies, the though of danger and the constant, unnerving lack of recognition: it doesn't take much to push the crew over the brink between obedience and its opposite. They unite behind the charisma of their chaplain and drift away from the authority of the first lieutenant.
802042: Have the lieutenant meet the unofficial leader
802043: Offer a rise to the chaplain
802044: Make an example out of the ring leader
802045: Ignore the discontent and let it wane
802046: The two men reach an understanding. The chaplain's demands are understandable, and the first lieutenant's limits are logical. Both agree on working to reach a better balance of power and supply repartition within the crew, and they leave satisfied with the encounter. A fair outcome for everyone.
802047: The discussion reaches an end, somehow. The first mate doesn't listen to the chaplain and the chaplain doesn't hear the first mate. Their to-ing and fro-ing is exasperating even to their own allies. After an endless debate over meaningless details, the two men seem to reach an agreement and shake on it, ending the hostilities. In truth, the established innovations are nothing more than old measures with new faces: novelty, not change.
802048: There is no trust to be found in the rebel's hearts. The chaplain refuses to meet your first lieutenant on the deck and invites him to join him in his own quarters instead: in short, in hostile territory.
802049: Negotiate with the chaplain in his quarters
802050: That's enough disobedience, arrest the chaplain
802051: The lieutenant manages to reason with the chaplain. The officer comes to the ringleaders' quarters unarmed, and stands his ground while surrounded by nothing but hostile faces. He call to the faith of the chaplain and argues for a slow if deep change in the ship's line of command, offering his own position to the chaplain as long as he his kept as a close advisor. His stepping down is discouraging for the loyalists, but it was the only available option at this point.
802052: The meeting goes nowhere. With each new compromise offered by the first lieutenant the chaplain adds an additional request, growing more and more assured of his dominance in the current stalemate. The officer leaves with a list of impossible demands and the ringleader's followers stop working altogether. The ship comes to a stop, waiting for a decision to be made.
802053: The discussion is one-sided and disastrous. The first lieutenant barges in the chaplain's quarters and belches a series of commands, menacing the ringleader and his men of flogging, hanging, marooning and flogging again. The loyalists feel ashamed of following such a disrespectful idiot. Under the cover of the night, when the chaplain and his followers steal a long boat to desert the unbearable rule of the officers, many sailors follow. Less than half of the original crew remains.
802054: Be subtle, send the chaplain poisoned wine
802055: Be clear, arrest the chaplain for high treason
802056: Be ambiguous, ignore the chaplain's demands
802057: A swift and efficient assassination. Convinced of his advantage in the current situation, the chaplain gracefully accepts the first lieutenant's wine. The poison does not act immediately, but its effect is unequivocal: at dawn, the chaplain is bent over his desk, wide-eyed and grey as dust. No sailor dares to mention the reason for his death. Their caution enforces discipline, fear of their officers, and a general distrust of alcohol.
802058: The poison is obvious. The wine reeks, its smell so deadly and its color so murky it might as well have a skull and bones drawn on its label. The chaplain forces the lieutenant's envoy to drink the whole mixture. As the poor girl quivers and coughs blood and bile, the ringleader and his followers leave their quarters - by the time the envoy is dead, they are standing before the first lieutenant's cabin, armed and set on killing.
802059: In a final attempt at peaceful resolution, offer a bribe
802060: There is no choice but to confront them
802064: The bribe is enough, but its price goes beyond monetary value. The chaplain's despise for the first lieutenant spreads to the crew as they learn of the murder attempt, and the mob of sailors lock their officers in their cabins to stay there until the end of the trip. That they were not killed is the only victory the officers can enjoy.
802065: True anger can only be quelled with bribes of blood. The chaplain ignores the first lieutenant's plea. The man of faith pulls a rosary from his wrist, gestures for his men to act, and prays. With each bead which passes under his fingers a rebel plants his sword into the lieutenant, and as the officer screams so does the chaplain chants, louder and louder, until the prayer stops. When they leave the cabin, a new and mad order is established on the ship.
802066: Reinforcements come running at the lieutenant's call. The chaplain and his followers are surrounded and swiftly defeated, their strength no match for the loyalists' military training and devotion to their officers. Order is reinstated, the loyalists turned into a militia which reigns over the other sailors and suppresses any attempt at questioning the working conditions and power dynamics on the ship.
802067: The loyalists are less prepared, less convinced, and more brittle. The rebels break them, destroying what few sailors still tried to uphold discipline on the ship. The chaplain has the survivors attached to the mainmast and forced to drink poison, letting their corpses rot where they stand - a display which warns all sailors against condemning his actions. The trip continues under the rule of the chaplain, with the crew convinced that they just replaced a tyrant with another.
802068: The man of faith is captured and executed. The loyalists storm the chaplain's quarters and seize him before his followers can react - men used to fight with words can do little in the face of physical oppression. The chaplain is judged on the deck for all to see and hear, accused of high treason, then hanged on the mainmast and left to rot for a week. Fear keeps the sailors in check for the rest of the trip.
802069: The arrest is a bloodbath. If the loyalists had had an advantage in discipline or numbers, the arrest could have been quick. However, the whole crew enters the melee, sailors hitting each other blindly, unsure which side they're attacking and which they belong to. The chaplain is dragged across the deck and hanged without trial: a display of gratuitous violence which brings the sailors back to their senses. The body of the man of faith oscillates in the wind, shredded and limp, mirroring the crew.
802070: Inaction is not what the sailors hoped for. Both loyalists and rebels are dismayed by the absence of decision and restlessness spreads through the crew until the tension finally explodes: the first lieutenant is found dead in his quarters. The defiant act is not punished and most sailors interpret it as yet another sign of weakness, while others argue that the murder was judgment in and of itself.
802071: The loyalists' strength dwindles when facing friends. Loyalists and troublemakers collide in a short and feeble brawl, each side unable to give up or to kill their former crewmates. Shots willingly miss, slashes willingly fumble, punches willingly go limp. The fight goes out without a clear victor, and the rest of the trip is spent with both side wary of each other.
802072: The loyalists are too weak. The conflict erupts into an exchange of slurs, then blows, then gunshots. Men and women frantically try to kill sailors who were good friends and both first lieutenant and chaplain are no exceptions: the ring leader unexpectedly draw a sword and both men impale each other, their deaths signaling the end of the senseless fight. The crew collects its thoughts to mourn the man of Church for the efforts he put in for them.
802076: A pragmatic solution. The amount offered to the chaplain to buy his obedience is enough for the man of faith to ignore the incongruity of the monetary negotiations. With the roots of their problem still present the crew remains unruly, but the bought leader makes sure to maintain their anger at the lowest levels.
802077: The offer does not match the chaplain's expectations. If his calmness is to be bought, the price should be enough for him to share with all the sailors he roused. The offended man of faith retreats to his quarters without a word.
802078: The budding mutiny is easily crushed. The first lieutenant and two loyalists are all it takes to seize the chaplain and drag him to judgement: the man is condemned to be marooned on the next deserted island they find, and left to die at will or live in solitude. The swift arrest and punishment impresses the rest of the crew and renews their respect for their officers.
802079: The loyalists' strength dwindles when facing friends. Loyalists and troublemakers collide in a short and feeble brawl, each side unable to give up or to kill their former crewmates. Shots willingly miss, slashes willingly fumble, punches willingly go limp. The fight goes out without a clear victor, and the rest of the trip is spent with both side wary of each other.
802080: The loyalists are too weak. The conflict erupts into an exchange of slurs, then blows, then gunshots. Men and women frantically try to kill sailors who were good friends and both first lieutenant and chaplain are no exceptions: the man of faith unexpectedly draws a sword and both men impale each other, their deaths signaling the end of the senseless fight. The crew collects its thoughts to mourn the chaplain and the price he paid for them.
802081: Inaction is not what the sailors hoped for. Both loyalists and rebels are dismayed by the absence of decision and restlessness spreads through the crew until the tension finally explodes: the first lieutenant is found dead in his quarters. The defiant act is not punished and most sailors interpret it as yet another sign of weakness, while others argue that the murder was judgment in and of itself.
802084: Sailor under the mast! Weeks of harsh weather have taken their toll on the ship and the violent gusts of wind of this morning have toppled the mizzenmast. For a moment the ropes tying it to the other masts hold it in place, but there is only so much weight they can take: they break with a snap, letting the mizzenmast plummet on the deck. A sailor now wails, his leg caught under a pole twice his size.
802085: Cover the leg with a mix of water and soap and pull it away
802086: Cut the leg with a bone saw
802087: Lift the mast with a makeshift lever
802088: The sailor is easily pulled from under the mast. The foamy water allows the crushed leg to slither away from the debris and the limb emerges covered in rainbow bubbles and bloody splinters. The man will live and maybe, with a miracle or two, his leg will mend.
802089: An extreme but commendable choice. The sailor is given rum to drink and cloth to bite before he is held in place, his leg bound with a tight tourniquet. The doctor's labour is gruesome and the man can feel the grinding cuts as they tear through him, and he screams through the cloth and he howls and he roars - and yet the doctor stays composed and focused. When the leg is finally cut and the sailor dragged away, the crew feels that they are in capable hands.
802090: Butchery. The doctor's hands tremble more than his victim does, and the saw draws zigzags in the flesh, each cut unable to connect with the previous ones. The trapped sailor's screams become whimpers, then silence. The doctor has to be stopped before he can ruin any more of the unfortunate corpse, and his blood-clad figure sends a warning to whoever might ever need his help in the future.
802091: The man is freed. Using one of the partners broken by the mast, the crew fits the sturdy pieces of timber between the deck and the fallen mast, adding plank after plank in the opening and gradually raising the mast with ropes and pulleys tied to the mainmast. They manage to lift the mast long enough to free the sailor, and the doctor immediately tends to his crushed leg.
802092: The vague idea of a lever never becomes real. The sailors try to lift the mizzenmast by rolling logs underneath, but the huge wooden pole is far too heavy for its rolling movement to be controlled. The mast lurches forward and rolls from the sailor's leg to his chest, pushing his insides out. The view stays with the sailors for days before they can finally reach a decent harbour, get rid of the broken mast, and clean up the grisly mess underneath.
802095: Tangled! The Sargasso Sea was made famous by Columbus' sailors and their fear of entrapment: indeed, the vast surfaces of algae that stretch above the diamond waters look ominous, and their menace is confirmed by the ship standing still in their midst. Your own vessel avoids the brown plants, when a call rings from the stuck ship. There are still sailors onboard! You have no proper rescue equipment and risk getting tangled - should you try to help?
802096: A steam ship fears no entanglement - go rescue them!
802097: Help from a distance and fire a roped harpoon at their ship
802098: Do not take any risk and leave
802099: Your steam ship rides through the algae as if it was nothing. In fact, it is. The algae parts before your ship from the sole movement of the waves. Your sailors stay stunned as they see the legend break before them, and the rescued crew reveal their truth: it was the dreadfully calm winds of the Sargasso sea that caught their ship, not the flimsy algae. The saved sailors happily join your own and marvel at the steam ship's independence from the winds.
802100: A perfect shot. With just the right dosage of propulsion strength and aiming power, the harpoon strikes the stranded ship's starboard without damaging too much of its hull. The rope is collected by the crew onboard and they bind it to their railings before waiting for your instructions.
802101: Harpooning a ship without sinking it requires skills you crew doesn't have. The harpoon crashes into the stranded vessel and breaks through its starboard, allowing water to gush inside. Panicked screams emerge from the ship as several sailors jump into the water's algae in a desperate attempt to save themselves.
802102: Tie a buoy to the improvised zip line and create a transportation device
802103: Encourage the sailors to climb the rope and cross the distance on their own
802104: A flawless breeches buoy. The buoy is tied with ropes and cloth to create a solid leg harness, allowing the stranded sailors to be pulled to your ship in an almost comfortable manner. Once freed of the algae embarked on their clothes, the rescued crew eagerly offer their services to repay their life debt.
802105: The buoy comes undone with the first rescue attempt. As soon as a sailor climbs onto the contraption, it slips and swirls and sends him into the water. The ripples part the algae, revealing how meek the obstacle was: it was the still winds, not the plants, which prevented the ship from moving. The crews from both ships watch helplessly as the man drowns in the clear waters, before resuming their rescue in gloom and shame.
802106: A surge of courage animates the stranded sailors. Under the cheers of your crew and the repeated encouragements of your lieutenants, they grab the rope and, with the desperate strength of hope, they cross the distance to reach your ship. Their miraculous rescue leaves them stronger and confident in both their skills and your crew's good will - they join your sailors without a second thought.
802107: Hope alone cannot give them strength. Encouraged by your crew, one of the sailors of the stuck ship takes hold of the rope and suspends himself, legs crossed and hands gripping the hemp. As he begins his travel the coarse fibbers nibble his skin and the blood rushes to his head. He grabs a new handful of rope, fails, slips, falls. If he manages to climb back onboard, no other volunteer wishes to attempt the crossing, and you have to leave without a single sailor rescued.
802108: Send strong sailors with buoys to rescue them
802109: You will not risk sharing their entangled fate: leave
802110: The rescue is cruelly easy. Your sailors plunge into the waters and see the algae part before them: there's no real obstacle here. They grab the stranded crew as it drifts to them and bring them back onboard, where the rescued men explain that it was the dead winds which forced their ship to stay still. Their thankfulness is barely enough to erase your wasted efforts and the shame of your crew.
802111: The rescue is a failure. Your sailors push each other, trying to swim while pulling the huge buoys, and they paddle like young dogs discovering their first waters. They are exhausted way before they can reach the stranded ship, and they turn around despite your crew's encouragements and the lieutenants' orders. There is no ignoring the curses of the drowning sailors as your ship sails away.
802112: We did what we could. Fully aware that your crew's attempt did nothing but worsen the stranded sailors' fate, your lieutenants attempt a speech to lighten their burden. The sailors pretend to cheer up, but the thought of the abandoned ship stays with them.
802113: Someone better equipped might come their way. Or we will call for help at the next harbour. Or this could be a trap. Or we didn't really hear a call. Excuses after excuses are discussed this night, and none sounds true enough for the sailors' hearts to be at peace.
802116: Tremors, ash rain, light during night: it's an eruption! The island was too lush and bountiful to be harmless. The lava responsible for the fertile ground creeps from the mouth of the waking volcano and towards the jungle where a party of your men had erected camp for the night.
802117: Go back to the ship despite the darkness
802118: Find shelter against the incoming lava
802119: The ship is quickly found. The burning lights of the volcano illuminate the jungle and a handful of seasoned explorers lead the rest of the sailors back to the ship, zigzagging between shadows and fleeing animals. The vessel departs as the island is engulfed in flames, a vision as terrible as it is magnificent.
802120: The sailors are swallowed by the jungle's maze. Dense trees, moving shadows, screeching animals and the crew itself, whose silhouettes are deformed by the scorching heat. Too many visions allow panic to spread among the men, who cannot recognize the path and never make it back to the ship.
802121: Shelter! The crew finds a decrepit stone chapel, remains of a colonialist power, and deems it a better refuge than their cloth-made tents. An officer estimates that the lava will be on them soon: there's no choice but to spend the night here.
802122: Your crew is lost and perplexed. Your most committed explorers cannot wrap their heads around the complexity of the jungle, which changes with every new burnt tree, and it seems that every uncovered path might end in lava-devoured dead ends.
802125: Pray for the chapel to hold
802126: Dig trenches in the holy ground
802127: The chapel miraculously stands its ground. Lava rolls against its walls and forks around the white stone, melting its paint and parching its plaster. Nested on the only facade left untouched by the flow, the chapel's wooden door seems like the most fragile object the sailors have ever seen. When day comes they are safe and elated, and all kiss the blessed door before leaving.
802128: Their faith is nothing but hypocrisy in need. The crew remembers old aves from their worshipping days, but the years have eroded both their memory and their beliefs. They can only watch as the lava packs against the chapel's stained glass and breaks through. The spray of molten stone and broken glass scars all of them but kills none: a bite to remind them of their lack of dedication.
802129: The trenches are dug with military efficiency. Despite the darkness and the imminent danger, the sailors manage to dig deep trenches in no time and the pits redirect the lava as it flows in. The sailors snuggle in the chapel while lava runs around them, illuminating the stained glass, and they rejoice in the warm comfort of their shelter.
802130: Too much pressure and too little grit. The sailors can dig little more than scattered and knee-deep pits which have a negligible impact on the lava's course. As the crew scurries inside the chapel, so does the lava enters the sacred place and hugs the walls, its smoke burning throats and forever robbing the men of their voices.
802131: Follow a random animal and trust its instincts
802132: Pick a random path and trust your instincts
802133: All animals run to the beach, and your crew follows. Tracking down the herd of squealing, screeching, shrilling critters could be done with eyes closed and the sailors are led to the shore where they had beached. The ship departs in a hurry, leaving the animals to die into the ruthless volcano fire.
802134: Your hunters find no pattern in the animals' frenzy. The sailors run in a display of panic and poor judgment, mimicking the animals' despaired behavior. The crew still on the ship can only watch in horror as the island's greatest predator burns all preys, be they beast or human.
802135: Fear is the most reliable instinct. The sailors scamper through the jungle, chasing after their lava-created shadows. They stumble upon the beach by pure miracle and hop on the ship with the molten tongues on their heels, and the ship departs with a slightly charred hull but a safe crew.
802136: Fear is a treacherous adviser. Seeing that the only unburnt path is up, the sailors climb the jungle's trees in an attempt to escape the lava flow. Ground, then bark, then branches, then humans: everything burns. In the distance, the ship's remaining crew stay transfixed as they witness the volcano island devouring itself.
802139: "They steal your children?" The air hangs heavy around the sailors as their question withers in the hut. Their hosts consider the explorers, half-hopeful, half-eaten with the certitude that non-paying jobs are not the ones your crew enjoys. One child has to be offered with each new moon, an elder explains as she gestures towards the nearby river, or else bandits raid the surrounding settlements. Tomorrow, the bandits' steamboat will come to claim this village's due.
802140: Board the bandits' steamer with your gunboat
802141: Shadow the kidnappers back to their hideout with a river skiff
802142: Stay on your ship and deploy fire when the steamboat appears
802143: Ignore the bandits and go on your way
802144: Your assault is swift and without a single casualty. The kidnappers oppose no resistance when their carcass of a craft faces your own fresh-from-the-factory gunboat. They reluctantly lead you to their hideout, a sweatshop with no other employees than the stolen kids. Your crew sets the hideout afire, heads back to the village, and returns the children to their exulting parents: they give no rewards but smiles and tears, and your crew basks in this priceless payment.
802145: Your crew navigates through the mangrove with aplomb. The unusual environment doesn't manage to stop their steady rowing, and the sailors soon reach an outpost marking the entrance of the bandits' camp. Sobbing children are taken out of the kidnappers' steamboat and dragged towards a distant barn. Half a dozen armed men guard the building.
802146: The terrain is not one your crew is used to. They get stuck in the mangrove roots and their swearing can be heard all the way to the coast. When they manage to get free, the bandits' steamboat is waiting, its railings lined with guns.
802147: Rather than bandits, the crew finds their leftovers. The bayou's fog makes for a maze your sailors cannot navigate and they lose the bandits. They stumble upon both less and more than what they expected: a pit filled with torn shoes and their torn makers. The image stays with them until they try to describe it to the villagers and break down, unable to depict the young faces and their blank eyes. They leave, disgusted by their inability to end this savagery.
802148: Attack the bandits before they reach the barn
802149: Hide between the tree and wait for nightfall
802150: The bandits don't know what hit them. Using the element of surprise to their advantage, your sailors break into the camp and stifle the children's escorts before they can call for help. They hush the kids and squat behind what few bushes offer protection, monitoring the other bandits. The attack wasn't noticed.
802151: The sailors are unfit for a swift assault. Their choreographed clumsiness and dissonant roars drive the opponents back not because of their strength but because of the unconventional display. After an instant of bafflement, the kidnappers shout for others to join them and the whole gang soon surrounds your crew. They part to let their leader, a beast of a man, face the puny intruders.
802152: Go all out on the bandits and save the remaining children
802153: Acknowledge the danger and leave with what children are already saved
802154: Sailors and kids create a breathtaking chaos. The crew shoots and skewers while the children kick and bite their former oppressors, calling others to do the same. A deluge of shrieking kids and young adults emerges from the barn and attacks the guards, thrilled by your crew's display of strength. The band of unlikely fighters seize the bandits' steamboat, help themselves to their supplies, and triumphantly returns to the coast.
802155: Audacity does not make up for their lack of numbers. The crew manages to take down five guards before the noise attracts more armed bandits, and the sailors are driven back to their boat without a chance to liberate more children. The flee to the village and share what information they can with the villagers, glad to have freed some kids but aware that many more are still captive.
802156: The decision to run is not a simple one. The sailors recognize how dangerous the assault could be and retreat to the village with the few children they have saved. They share what information they can with the villagers - maybe another day, with a subtler approach, more men, more planning... As the ship leaves the crew focuses on the good they did, rather than the deeds they could have done.
802159: Your sailors' cause fuels their victory. Driven by their will to save the children, your sailors do not waver in front of the bandits' leader, all muscles and swords and wild eyes. It takes six fighters to face the man, piling up on him in a torrent of dust and groans until he finally stops rampaging. Disheartened by this defeat and their leader's meaningless pride, the remaining kidnappers are brought to their knees and the children are freed. The crew returns to the village triumphant!
802160: The mastodon tramples your sailors. The rescuers lack resistance and they are wiped by the bandits' leader, their corpses sent flying among the children who can do nothing but watch in horror. In a ultimate act of hatred, a young girl is sent back to her village to retell the carnage and warn future intruders against trying to rescue the children again.
802161: No sailor harmed, no child saved. The crew manages to run back to the village, avoiding the multiple gunshots fired by the kidnappers. That no sailor was wounded is a miracle, but it pales when your rescue team comes back with no rescued child.
802162: The crew merges with the trees. Unseen, unheard, the sailors bury themselves in the forest and observe their future targets. An opportunity arises when a group of bandits leave their posts to bathe in the river: splashing and talking, they do not hear your men approach.
802163: The sailors are not attuned to the notion of stealth. They argue about the best place to hide and end up lining behind what could be the thinnest trees of the forest, their racket and bulging shapes attracting the undivided attention of the kidnapers. Their leader, more beast than man, advances to inspect the intruders and laughs at the puny men.
802164: Steal their clothes to disguise as bandits
802165: Capture the men to use them as hostages
802166: Your sailors in disguise orchestrate the children's escape. Dressed with the bandits' rough coats and sashes, the crew infiltrates the barn turned sweat shop where children are forced to work. One by one they lead the kids out of the camp and into their skiff, each child carrying stolen supplies: when the boat finally leaves, the camp is left without fuel, food, or ammunitions. It will be some time before the bandits can do any more harm.
802167: The poorly-disguised intruders are identified and given chase. When asked by an actual bandit about their shift, one of your undercover sailors tries to answer: they fumble and bumble until the bandit grabs them and shouts for intruders. They make a run for it with the others, leaving both kidnappers and children behind.
802168: A flawless action, from start to finish. After a swift capture of the naked bandits, the sailors advance and discover the camp's true nature: a children-powered sweatshop. It is soon obvious that the bandits' leader is the only one who does not care for the hostages, and the man is forcibly exchanged by his crew against the promise that your sailors will never set foot here again. The rescuers come back with children on their shoulders, a culprit to be judged, and goods to be shared.
802169: The naked men overpower your fighters. The element of surprise does not compensate the lacking strength of the crew, and they are easily repelled by the bathing bandits. Instead of killing them, the kidnappers order the sailors to strip and send them back as is, rescuers unable to retrieve the children and humiliated in the process.
802172: The crew is puny indeed, and it is butchered. The bandits' leader needs no help to fight your rescuers, who spend more time trying to avoid being hit than actually fighting back. They flee the camp, scatter into the woods, and are hunted down like game. The few sailors who make it back to the coast can't even determinate the location of the kidnappers' camp, making the deaths of their companions pointless.
802173: Bluff and pretend backup is on its way
802176: Your bluff works! The kidnappers have a heated discussion before handing over what few children they have onboard, pressed by the menace your crew just invented. The sailors retreat to the village and deliver the kids, still amazed by their performance but upset they could save so little.
802177: They do not buy your bluff. Holding your crew at gunpoint, the bandits casually wait for the reinforcements to show up. They don't. To teach your crew a lesson, the kidnappers grab one of the kids onboard and cut his tongue before throwing it into your raft: a lesson for liars. Your sailors withdraw to the village, convinced they made things worse.
802181: A pricey but worthy trade. Trying to hide their distaste for treating children like goods, your sailors bring the kids onboard. They are in a state of shock but look physically sound.
802183: The children are safe with you, punish their abductors
802184: The children will be safer with their parents, let the kidnappers leave
802186: Your retribution is ruthless. The kidnappers are still counting the goods you bought the children with when the crew attacks, and its assault is brutal. The steamboat is set aflame and all bandits die by fire or bullet. The crew brings the kids back to the safety of their homes, but the children now see them as no different from their captors: beasts driven by violent instincts.
802187: Your sailors are overpowered. The kidnappers have fought much harder battles against much less men, and your crew's attack is dismissed with scorn. They could easily have retrieved the children, but their strange sense of honor makes them consider that goods bought are goods acquired. The crew is sent back to the village with the kids, both looking equally dishevelled and aghast.
802188: Pity to let the culprits escape so easily. The sailors bring the children back to their respective families, but the kids' joy fails to hide how many more could have been saved given an extra effort.
802189: You do not match the bandits' expectations. To teach your crew a lesson, the kidnappers grab one of the kids onboard and cut his thumb before throwing it into your raft: a lesson for the penniless. Your sailors withdraw to the village, convinced they made things worse.
802190: There's only so much your sailors can do. They back away under the menace of the bandits' guns, doing their best not to trigger an attack, and row back to the coast. The parents of the abducted children thank them for the effort, but their strangled hopes make their voices break. The sailors leave knowing they could have done better.
802191: A masterful shot! Using one of your precious spiral-muzzled cannons, the crew fires a single shot which pierces straight through the steamboat's engines. The boat gradually stops puffing and drifts to your own ship, where sailors can pluck the bandits and three stolen children.
802192: Poor use of your firepower. The sailors handling the cannons and the weapons themselves are equally important: not as well-oiled as the machinery, the crew fails to adjust the quantity of powder used, firing the artillery to its maximum range without any kind of aiming. They might as well have lit signal fires. The bandits' boat makes a brutal turn and retreats in the bayou at full speed.
802193: Both bandits and captives are killed. The villagers watch in horror as your ship fires its cannons at the small steamboat as soon as it is in sight, annihilating the frail vessel and all life onboard. Mothers and fathers rush in the water, screaming and crying as tiny bodies slowly emerge. If your crew had had a greater control over themselves and the ship, maybe they wouldn't have had to bear the weight of these children's deaths.
802194: Scare the kidnappers into revealing the position of their hideout
802196: Enough risks for today: return the children and be on your way
802197: Your seafarers coerce the river-dwellers into saying the truth. There is a world of knowledge and pain into your men's eyes, and the bandits are overwhelmed by their presence before a single word is spoken. The revealed hideout is an easy prey for your crew, which storms through the den and triumphantly bring all children back to their parents, along with the bandits' possessions and supplies.
802198: The intention is here, but not the result. The bandits recognize your sailors for what they are: sharp-shooters indeed, but weaklings when it comes to close-range confrontation. The crew's threats are nothing to them. Knowing that these men know where the rest of the children are held, your crew hands them to the villagers along with the kids they found, and leave with a feeling of defeat.
802199: Thoughts of the remaining captives follow your crew. The villagers are thrilled to have the handful of children returned to them and profusely thank their saviors, making their remorse worse with each new praise. The sailors are happy for them but know they could have done more.
802200: Not all sailors share your lack of compassion. Some men and women refuse to leave and the officers have no choice but to let them do as they please lest they'd lose even more of the crew's trust. Many sailors argue that staying to help was the right choice, but the ship has already set sail when they voice their opinion.
802201: Shadow the kidnappers back to their hideout with a river skiff
802204: The splendid warriors are all women. Exploring the deserted coastal settlement was a nice opportunity for looting, but it seems your crew wasn't the only one to get this idea. As they push the village's rundown barricade, they happen upon a group of warriors who immediately assume a defensive formation in a motion almost too perfect to be human. There's not a single man among them.
802205: Let a woman do the talking
802208: The warriors greatly enjoy your specialist's company. Glad to see a fellow woman act as a presence of power, the fighters invite your crew to share the bounty of their raiding: despite the difference in tongue and civilization, your sailors enjoy a feast of exotic game and liquor and spend the night improvising songs and dances with the women.
802209: Your diplomat dispels the barrier of language. Mimicking the sailors' trip through the seas and showing the women their ship, maps and supplies, the diplomat manages to have them understand the goals of your crew. The warriors eagerly observe your charts and point out what areas your ship should investigate next - their excitement suggesting their own love of discovery. Crew and women part with the conviction of having met like-minded explorers.
802210: Groveling is not respect. Your diplomat treats the women like savages, kneeling before them and uttering oooh and aaah sounds which are seen as insulting even by the crew. One of the female warriors steps forward and plants a lance in his thigh.
802211: Respond to their violence in kind
802213: Your guns provide an underhanded upper hand. While the warriors fight with lances and short war hammers, your sailors draw their pistols and fire them at will. The women draw back, dragging their wounded and dead away, while your crew savor the bitter victory. How would they have fared without the guns?
802214: Small arms, huge defeat. The sailors fire their pistols at the women in a clumsy and disorganized manner, which cannot hold against the warriors' discipline and flawless coordination. Walking on the corpses of their own kin, the women pierce through your ranks and slaughter them. They spare what few explorers were women and let them run back to the ship.
802215: The women look interested but cautious.
802218: The exotic supplies intrigue the warriors. Curiosity replaces their anger and seeing how fascinated they are by the crew's maps, the sailors guess that the women might share their taste for exploration. Sadly, it is too late to earn the warriors' trust and they leave with your presents in silence.
802219: A waste of time. The warriors barely have the time to examine your supplies that an officer barks an order to pull the crates back into the ship, leaving the women baffled and offended. The officer heads flies and the warriors cleave through your sailors until they reach your cargo. They leave with a tall barrel of liquor and disappear from the scene of carnage.
802220: Your crew's deference pleases the warriors. Surprised by the sailors bowing before them in respect, the women giggle and lower their guard. They tap the explorers' chins with the tip of their lances, inviting them to drop their hunching position for a proper face-to-face. Although they do not share a language, they manage to communicate through their love of meat and drink, and the feast lasts deep into the night.
802221: Can these men show real respect? Your sailors cannot translate their admiration in their acts. They crawl to the women and hold their hands, letting their sweat soil the soft skin and their eyes trail the soft shapes. One of the warrior spits to their face in disgust. The other women imitate her and walk away, whispering among themselves.
802223: Ignore the humiliation and let them leave
802224: The assault is one-sided. Your sailors draw their guns and shoot the warriors in their backs, taking down the women with ease and ganging up against the remaining ones. Reassured of their fortitude, the men leave the settlement and try to ignore the debasing aspect of this unnecessary bloodshed.
802225: Skill, conviction, discipline: your men lack them all. They draw their guns and fire at the women, who react at once and pounce on their assailants. Short war hammers appear in their hands and end up in skulls. One hit, one kill. Terrified by the warriors' martial ability, the survivors abandon the fight and run back to the ship.
802226: The sailors feel humiliated. They let the warriors leave and console themselves as they can by looting the remains of the settlement, but the women have left no stone unturned. Empty-handed and disgraced, they go back to the ship.
802229: Boulder-blocked entrance and booby-trapped corridor: typical Mayan temple. After a fall down a slide and a crash into uncharted caves, your team of explorers jokes about the situation to forget its deathly aspect. They know what is said of Mayan mazes: the deeper you go, the shinier it gets.
802230: Follow the suggested route and progress through the traps
802231: Create your own path and push the boulder away
802232: The obvious traps are easily evaded. The sailors contort themselves to avoid sharp stones and plated triggers, flowing through the corridor with the ease of seasoned explorers, or cutpurses. They quickly reach the pocket of the temple: a vast chasm crossed by a meager bridge with no handrails. Could this be a trial of courage?
802234: The trial is passed! As they swing their arms to keep their balance, your sailors hit ropes suspended around the bridge, hidden by a clever camouflage of paint and shadow play. They grasp the ropes to steady their footing and a distant mechanism clicks. A rumbling door opens on the other side of the chasm, revealing the exit and, on its threshold, a shiny artifact.
802235: Nothing rewards your sailors' recklessness. It is unclear whether the bridge is shaking because of its own frailty or because of your explorers' quivering legs. Soon the crew is on its knees, creeping across the moldy planks and begging for their mothers. They reach the other side without a scratch save for their wounded pride and find a tunnel which leads them outside after some more crawling.
802237: The climb is child's play. Rock walls provide a much steadier footing than wind-flogged masts. The sailors reach the bottom of the chasm, where they find an army of ropes stretching into the darkness above: the entrails of the temple's mechanisms! They find what might have been the Mayan engineers' entrance and leave the temple with filled pockets and memories.
802238: The effort is above the crew's strength. An officer loses her nerve and her grip, slips down the stone, and a soft thud welcomes her fall. Smooth slithering sounds hush her desperate cries. The floor is covered in snakes!
802239: Find a way among the snakes
802240: Scare the snakes away with torches
802241: The sailors manage to flee. Too occupied by the convulsing mass of the fallen officer, the reptiles do not notice the furtive crew as it tip toes past them and escapes through the first tunnel available. The explorers emerge outside of the temple, stunned by their survival.
802242: They cannot read the snakes' behaviour. The sailors progress among the wriggling floor, so focused on their movements they do not see the mass of snakes backing away from them and piling against the sole exit. The crew has no choice but to run into the tunnel before it is filled with snakes, and several sailors end up as reptile diner.
802243: The crew stands its ground as well as it can. The burning torches are swung before the snakes, forcing them back from both sailors and prey. The officer is pulled to her feet and dragged with the rest of the crew through a windy tunnel which leads them outside, empty-handed but safe.
802244: What should the snakes be scared of, exactly? Your crew flaps the torches around them in a ballet of shaking hands and dripping sweat, and they cannot even make one step forward that a young sailor waves his torch past the limits of safety. The snakes leap on your crew, leaving none but a single witness alive.
802245: The challenge demands more coordination than the crew has. Surprised by the brushing elbow of a comrade, a sailor squeals in terror and jumps back, triggering trap after trap of flying arrows, flaming oils, poison sprays. Once the most sensational traps have simmered down, the roof collapses and seals the exit. Sand slowly starts to fall from the walls.
802246: Look for a possible hidden mechanism
802249: The patterns of the mechanism do not escape your hunters' probing. Upon close and cool-headed inspection, one the sand-spewing hourglass engravings appears to be protruding from the wall. The sailors smash the button, forcing the wall to open and reveal an exit. They immediately run away from the sand and the temple itself.
802250: If there is a mechanism, they do not find it. Sand keeps pouring into the room, ricocheting off the sailors, blinding them, forcing its way into their noses and mouth. The explorers utter muted screams. As the sand packs against the walls, one of them crumbles under the weight and lets the sailors spill outside of the temple: some alive, most dead.
802251: The old wall caves in effortlessly. Following the sand-pouring cracks, the explorers identify the wall from which most grains seem to be coming. They stave it in, causing a dusty outpour which fills their lungs then clears to reveal sunlight. They hasten through the self-made exit and end up on the beach where they had left the ship.
802252: The explorers bang on the walls helplessly. Sand keeps pouring into the room, ricocheting off the sailors, blinding them, forcing its way into their noses and mouth. The crew utters muted screams. As the sand packs against the walls, one of them crumbles under the weight and lets the sailors spill outside of the temple: some alive, most dead.
802253: The boulder moves! The combined efforts of the crew manage to lift the giant stone out of its socket. As the boulder rolls, a loud snap resonates and the rock bounces back in place. A wall falls behind the sailors and, in a concert of grating dirt and destroyed stone, it starts to advance towards the crew.
802254: The boulder doesn't move. Your explorers push and nudge and thrust but the exit stays sealed. They have no choice but to obey the maze's invitation.
802255: Push against the wall to stop it
802257: The ancient wall cannot resist your crew's pressure. They grunt in unison and breathe in rhythm with their effort. One, two. The wall stops in its tracks. One. It shivers. Two. The wall crumbles, revealing a large opening under its railings: the crew finds the body of a less lucky adventurer, one hand clawing at the threshold of a gaping exit, the other gripping an oversized diamond.
802258:
The wall is unfazed by your crew's efforts. As an explorer gets to her knees to pray in the face of imminent death, she notices an engraving much less elaborate than the temple's decorations: scribbled letters in a language she can actually understand!
"Crawling by day, airborne by night."
Right underneath the scribbling are four buttons depicting animals.
802263: Wrong answer. The brick above the pressed button opens and an arrow flies into the crew, perforating the throat of a sailor and leaving a red line in the cheek of the button-presser. The floor under the explorers tilts and they roll, a helpless mass of arms and legs which slides along the tunnel and is expelled outside the temple.
802264: Wrong answer. As she presses the button, the sailor feels no resistance and keeps pushing the carved stone until her full arm is into the wall. She can feel something furry on her skin, if a bit rough and a bit- She screams. As fangs dig into her flesh, a legion of bats emerge from the opened wall, forcing the sailors to retreat through their nest. The crew emerges from the temple covered in blood and crippled with a lasting fear of the dark.
802265: Right answer! The sailor hits the butterfly button and jubilates as the trap wall stops advancing and bricks whirl into the floor to shape a staircase. The crew emerges from the temple, wondering about the intentions of whoever had carved such needlessly complicated indications in their mother tongue.
802266: Wrong answer.As the cockroach is pressed, the insect shivers and shakes the dust off its shell. It's alive! The ceiling opens and a swarm of cockroaches flies into the room, aiming for the sailors' mouths. The crew smashes the insects with whatever object they have at hand and their horror gives them wings of their own, pushing them to climb the walls until they reach the outside.
802267: The unfazed explorers rapidly find an exit. They notice how the floor's cobblestones move to let the advancing wall pass, and wait for the right moment to jump into the space between wall and floor. One by one they land into the room below, where a large opening to the outside lets morning light in and reveals a spectacle of spiderwebs surrounding a delicate piece of sculpted mahogany.
802268: The sailors do not find an exit. All stones look alike, and the crew lacks the ability to appraise which rock might be more important than the others. The advancing wall looms over, ready to crush their bones, when it suddenly leans forward and pushes the sailors to the floor, which in turn opens to eject the explorers outside the temple. They are alive, but the very sight of stone walls will scare them for years.
802270: The lookout is sure of himself: he saw a mermaid. Despite the burning sun of noon, sailors pile up against the ship's handrails and inspect the mirror waters for more signs of the creature. At last, they glimpse its silver tail and hear its song, a mesmerizing chant which beckons them.
802272: Have an expert examine the apparition
802274: The mermaid is half-fish, half-fish. The scientist orchestrates a careful operation to retrieve the animal from the ocean, sending divers underwater to lure and catch the creature by playing with it. The miniature whale enjoys singing with your sailors for the rest of the trip.
802275: Answer the mermaid with a sailing chant
802276: Not one, but a dozen mermaids answer the chant. As your crew sings of their country ruling the waves and their patriots never being slaves, the marine creatures react joyfully and surround the ship, jumping along its sides. These animals are no mermaids. They're frisky little whales!
802277: Try to catch one of them
802278: An effortless catch for your fishermen. Taking care not to hurt the beautiful creatures, the sailors casts multiple nets in the water and retrieve an individual from the pack, quickly transferring it to one of your wildlife aquariums. The animal seems to enjoy the constant attention and the free food, and the crew falls in love with the playful "mermaid."
802279: Your fishermen are not used to catching fish alive. They cast a weighted nest among the pack, but as they try to pull it up the animal slips out, its tangled flipper striped with thin red lines. The creatures flee underwater, leaving the sailors longing for their song.
802281: The moment is otherworldly. The creatures dance among the waves, tweeting and clicking in response to your sailors' cheers, jumping higher with each new verse sung by their human admirers. Their ballet and innocent happiness is well worth the absence of mermaids.
802282: The mermaid vanishes. The crew sings with more passion than prowess, and the creature itself doesn't deign to answer. When at last their breath is short, the sailors mourn the disappearance of the mermaid and waste more time dreaming up her sisters and their underwater kingdoms.
802283: A sailor jumps into the ocean! Unfazed by the crew's heartfelt singing and longing for her, the mermaid flips her tail, teasing and staying underwater. Spurred by the chanting, one of your men leaps into the sea and is now gurgling and splashing in a parody of swimming technique, desperate to follow the creature.
802284: Go after the mermaid and the drifting sailor
802285: Close enough for one last glimpse of the mermaid. The ship slides aside the creature and the frenzied sailor swimming after it. The mermaid splashes her tail at her stalker and disappears, allowing the fallen man to be dragged back onboard, where he is immediately pressed by jealous questions. Alas, the sailor saw little of the frightened creature and its true form remains a mystery.
802286: The maneuver sends the ship crashing against both man and mermaid. Too eager to catch up with the beautiful creature, several sailors grapple the steering wheel and fight to guide the ship, oblivious to the alarmed instructions of their officers. The iron prow crushes the mermaid and her follower. When they come to their senses, the sailors are not punished: their horror and shame is sanction enough.
802287: Let the fool face his fate
802288: The smitten sailor drowns. The man paddles against the light waves, his skull going in and out of the water, his lips moving feverishly and the sea sounds keeping his words for themselves. When his head doesn't resurface, the sailors know the mermaid had nothing to do with it.
802289: Convince the sailors of ignoring the creature
802290: Discipline is stronger than fascination. Galvanized by the orders of their officers, the sailors ignore the mermaid's calls and leave it behind, fulfilling their duty. They feel like heroes of ancient tales in the face of mystical temptations and the epic trial makes them shiver in pride.
802291: Fascination gets the better of your crew's discipline. The men ignore all orders and deliberate among themselves, planning the best approach to catch the mermaid's attention. The officers cannot accept this undermining of their authority, and get the whips ready.
802293: Give the dissidents a good flogging
802294: Action commands respect. Four of the most unruly sailors are dragged to the stern, tied in kneeling positions, and flogged until their shirts are drenched. Acceptance spreads within the crew as their minds clear, and they resume their duties knowing that this expedition will tolerate no mischief. The mermaid was a nice but short-lived dream.
802295: The flogging exceeds discipline and goes overboard. Instead of organizing a session of punishment, with explicit rules, blames and sanctions, the officers chastise at will, whipping whoever is within reach, spitting their anger in unintelligible tirades. When they calm down, the dissidents are a mass of sweat, blood, and whimpers. The mermaid cries in the distance as the crew resumes its duties.
802296: Drop the issue and let them be
802297: Discipline aboard this ship is lax. Convinced that their misconduct can go unpunished, the sailors take to ignore or bargain the officers' orders, and "mermaid" becomes a keyword to rally against tedious instructions. This behaviour plagues the rest of the trip.
802300: A kraken! The rainstorm parts to reveal tentacles wide as a barrel and long as ten men, snaking between the waves. The creature of legends is heading towards the ship at full speed.
802301: Fire a torpedo at the beast
802304: The so-called beast is no match for a torpedo. Firing a torpedo is a first for most of your crew, yet they manage to handle the unusual weaponry with skill. The self-propelled projectile flies underwater and crashes into the kraken with an explosion that shakes the storm itself. One more tale to tell back home!
802306: If harpoons can kill whales, they can kill monsters. Despite the pounding rain and poor visibility, the sailors manage to load a harpoon and fire it at the kraken: the beast shakes, flails, and disappears into the sea under the triumphant cheers of the crew.
802307: Panicked men try to shoot at the monster. The bullets drop into the water like meaningless pebbles and do no harm to the kraken except rouse its anger. Flailing its tentacles, the creature hits the ship with full force and soon ensnares the boat.
802309: The gigantic tentacles are sawed off. Using the engineers' oversized ship saw, the sailors manage to cut through the elastic flesh of the monster. The kraken convulses and lets go of ship, leaving the crew to repair the boat and wipe out what gooey blood was spilled on the deck.
802310: Measly men make no miracles. The sailors assault the tentacles, trying to plant what swords and knives and forks they have at hand into the thick flesh. The suckers stay glued to the deck. The beast shakes and its suckers tremble, extending for a tense second before bouncing back up, taking large parts of the deck with them. Wood and metal rain over the sailors and the kraken leaves them to die.
802312: The creature matches your strength for a short while. It grabs the ship and rocks it, shaking several cannons away from their sailors. The remaining artillery is fired without delay and strikes the kraken into submission, sending it back to the depths it came from. The sailors have but light repairs to perform on the cannons.
802313: The power of the beast largely surpasses yours. A glassy eye levels with the deck, reflecting the sailors's silhouettes as they make hurried preparations to shoot the cannons. The cannonballs fly by the kraken and leave it unscathed, allowing it to grapple and tip over the ship with its unsheathed hooks, pouring sailors into its beak. It then disappears from your crew's sight, but not their nightmares.
802316: Full steam ahead! Using the full power of your steam ship, the vessel leaps and tears through the waves, leaving the kraken to swirl in its wake. A sailor blows the ship's horn to salute the creature and watches in delight as it plunges back into the ocean.
802317: The wind is ideal for such a maneuver. Your navigators and sailors rush to their posts and work to align ship and storm, fusing the vessel with the elements. The wind carries the ship away from the kraken, and delivers it to a sunny clearing of calm and monsterless waters.
802318: Your crew cannot outmaneuver the storm. They wrestle the wind and rain, their struggle showing in the chaotic movements of the ship. The kraken slips under the vessel and emerges in front of it, stopping any escape attempt by ensnaring the prow in its tentacles.
802321: These tracks could belong to maneaters. The crew's reconnaissance report carried intriguing rumours of local threats: abducted men and women, quarries filled with human bones, and a mountain chain too impenetrable to be devoid of valuable finds. Almost as soon as your explorers start their ascension, they spot fresh tracks in the dry leaves.
802323: Your sailors follow the tracks without trouble. The trail of footprints runs among the mountain's trees, zigzaging among dead leaves and fallen trunks, disappearing under the steps of your explorers. It leads the sailors deep into the forest, to a clearing where a tiny village is nested. Under the tiled roofs of their Old World homes, the inhabitants are white-skinned and blue-eyed. If they are cannibals, they don't look the part.
802324: Engage a friendly conversation with the inhabitants
802325: Your diplomat realizes that the autochthons speak a similar language. The blue-eyed inhabitants answer in a patois laced with foreign expressions and sounds, but there is no mistaking the origins of their dialect. Pleased by the diplomat's banter, they invite your crew to share a feast of exotic meats and vegetables, and describe the grand adventures of their ancestors to your fascinated crew: tales of exiled war prisoners and their fight to create a new home.
802326: The diplomat mistakes civilized aspect for civilized behaviour. She strides straight into the village, confident in the autochthons' pacifism, and spreads her arms to the nearest woman - a young girl who shrieks upon seeing her and bites the welcoming hand. The alerted villagers surround your diplomat with pitchforks and shovels. They creep on her, poking her with their improvised weapons.
802327: Face the villagers to rescue your diplomat
802328: The crew manages to rescue her. Taking advantage of the villagers' obsession with the intruder, the sailors surround them and attack as one in a flurry of gunshots and slicing swords. Visibly terrified by the pistols and unable to face the military unison of your crew, the autochthons flee and leave the diplomat to be rescued. Wether the encounter could have been solved peacefully, you will never know.
802329: Your crew is overwhelmed. They attempt a clumsy charge, overlooking any assessment of the enemy's strength, and crash against the wall of peasants' weapons. They disband as fast as they engaged the fight and become easy targets for the villagers, who gleefully hunt them and cheer each time a sailor is struck down. The rare survivors are left to ponder what grim fate awaits those who were captured.
802332: Run, run away! Leaving your diplomat to face the villagers alone, the crew flees back to the ship. As they bury into the forest they hear a sudden and hideous scream, which ends as brutally as it erupted. No sailor comment on the voice: they all recognized the diplomat.
802333: Survey the village's activity from a distance
802334: The crew is undetected and detects nothing of interest. Your sailors conceal themselves among the trees and observe the villagers from a distance, too far from their activities to understand the reasons for the inhabitants' busy bustle. They return to the ship without proof nor denial of the rumoured cannibalism.
802336: You call that discreet? The sailors tiptoe around the village, stopping every few feet to comment on which branch they should or shouldn't step on, so focused on their feet they do not even consider how the wind carries their sounds and smells. When they finally raise their heads, an army of pitchforks welcomes them.
802337: Apologise to the villagers for trespassing
802338: Your diplomat manages to be understood. She mumbles a variety of foreign words until the villagers, touched by her efforts, respond. Their language is intelligible, if made of outdated expressions: a testimony to their ancestors, they say, war prisoners sent to die here generations ago. They leave little doubt regarding which country sent them. Your sailors are ushered away before they can inquire about the villagers' past or their dietary habits.
802339: Rather than apologise, your diplomat crawls. She tugs at the villagers' sleeves and shows how unarmed she is, advising your sailors to drop their own weapons in order to display their benevolence. Rather than restraint, the villagers see submission. They take the weaponry and let the sailors escape in exchange for the diplomat - the last your crew sees of her is her figure tied to a towering pole, for a purpose best left unknown.
802341: Where discretion fails, force prevails. Your crew is unfazed by the villagers and springs to action: its sudden and precise attack knocks them down and their resistance drowns under the repeated assaults of the sailors. About half of the sailors makes it back to the ship, the others fallen prey to the maneating mountain.

802354: The guide waits for an offer.

802362: Interpret the carvings on the stone

The pyramidal cave beyond doesn't look like a city, but it is indeed filled with precious artifacts.

802373: Enter the cave and pray for guidance

802384: Ignore the voice as the priest advises

"Surely God is my salvation,

"Hassan Ben Sahid salutes you with his last breath.
Upon you the gifts of true solace and rebirth,
While I lay asleep in the lavish lap of earth.
May mercy find you despite my earliest death."
