Hidden in the hull and unable to do anymore for their ship, the crew must wait for the storm to calm down on its own.
802510: Mayhem. Disheartened by the enormity of the task, the sailors hardly listen to their lieutenants. Four crew members attempt to follow orders and unfasten the deck's supplies, which roll away from them and swing through the deck as the ship continues to pitch, knocking down sailors and pushing them overboard, breaking the ship's railings and toppling its weakened masts. When the sun emerges, it reveals the emaciated silhouette of a ghost ship.
802511: Slow and steady.Maybe too slow? Careful maneuvers maintain your ship under favourable winds and keep the menace of transverse waves at bay, but the storm still rages and, worse, it keeps up with your pace.
802512: You would have been better off with a windjammer. Navigating the ship through the storm proves trickier than expected, and the navigators' lack of familiarity with steam ships shows as they rely on the sails to maneuver, despite the ship's peculiar lack of a middle mast. It doesn't take long for the ship to protest against the poor handling. It yaws, and a loud rumble erupts from the hull: the ballast is unfastened!
802513: Overheat the engines to outrun the storm
802514: Maintain a steady pace and let the storm push you off-tracks
802515: A power stronger than the elements themselves. Through skillful manipulation of the engines, the crew pushes the machinery to its utmost limit, the screw propeller moving beyond what human sight can perceive and propelling the steam ship with remarkable speed. The vessel breaks through the waves and away from the storm in a thrilling display of man-made might.
802516: You should have been more patient. The crew cannot manage such a brusque change of pace, and their meager knowledge of the machinery is not enough to demand so much from the engines without paying an equivalent price. The ship vaults away from the storm in a cacophony of complaining metal and agonizing devices - when at least the tempest is gone, the engines require your immediate attention and repairs.
802521: Fasten the ballast back into place
802522: Fight the pitching with a bold attempt at facing the wind
802523: Your sailors are unperturbed by the pitching. They descend into the hull and avoid the rolling basalt stones with ease, tying the ballast back in place, stone by stone, knot by knot. They emerge bruised and exhausted, but the ship is now steady enough to wait for the storm to pass without any risk of broaching.
802524: Too heavy, too dangerous. Your sailors are ill-prepared to handle the massive basalt stones that act as ballast. They try to secure the stones in place but the ship continues to pitch and their footing is unsteady and the rocks are so, so heavy. A sudden yaw sends the basalt rolling into them and your sailors are knocked down and crushed like clay figures. There is nothing more to be done but wait for the ire of the tempest to pass.
802525: Indeed, this is a windjammer. Navigating the steam ship like a good old sailboat, the navigators rely on the sails alone to steady the erratic movements, and strain the rudder to face a full frontal wind. This is fearless! The gale hits the wet sails with all its might, inflating them to their utmost limit, and the sudden force breaks the pitching. The navigators immediately seize the opportunity to restart the engines and escape the storm under the delighted clamor of the crew.
802526: Disaster. Proving once more how unable they are to navigate the ship, the navigators attempt what should never be attempted: go against the wind. As the ship twirls the transversal gale strikes it with full force, transforming the yaw into a full-length broaching. The masts plunge into the sea, and there is no more up or down, no more sky or deck. Everything is water. When it drains away, allowing the ship to sway back into position, there is no trace left of the sailors taken by the storm.
802527: A power stronger than the elements themselves. Through skillful manipulation of the engines, the crew pushes the machinery to its utmost limit, the screw propeller moving beyond what human sight can perceive and propelling the steam ship with remarkable speed. The vessel breaks through the waves and away from the storm in a thrilling display of man-made might.
802528: The delicate machinery is handled brutishly. Assuming that the engines heat is directly proportional to the ship's speed, the engineer overheats the steamer and bring the boiler way over its capacity. The temperature rises and the pressure swells and the metal quivers, until one of the engine explodes, killing the engineer on the spot.
802529: Attempt to use the remaining engine without your engineer
802530: Shut off the engines and rely on your sails
802531: An unexpected turnaround. A sailor steps forward: she's spent the trip observing the engineer, she says, and thinks she can handle the machinery. The lack of other volunteers, frightened by the engineer's death, leaves her as the only candidate. She handles the remaining engine with a notable if amateurish skill and the steam ship emerges from the storm in one piece. Still, several sailors whisper about the ill luck of letting a woman save them.
802533: From bad to worse. The sailors have even less skill than the engineer who, let us insist on this point, died while trying to practise his specialty. The crew tries to push this thing and pull that other thing. The pieces of metal are kicked to the best of the crew's abilities until the air pump's valve bursts open, filling the entire room with burning steam and forcing the sailors outside. The valve must be closed, and a volunteer offers to face the miniature hell.
802534: Forget engineering, and hope the Lord will protect the volunteer
802536: Insist on using your crafting wits, and protect him yourself
802537: If not skill, at least courage is rewarded. The volunteer rushes inside the engine room to close the leaking valve, screaming a Glory Be as the steam broils his skin. Both steam and storm recede once the valve is slammed closed, and the crew can take its time repairing the abused machinery. The volunteer spends the rest of the trip preaching the Lord's grace and his incessant sermon make the other sailors regret the tempest and its terrifying shrieks.
802538: Hell indeed. Whether the volunteer lacked faith or the Lord lacked attention, it is only for Him to know. The man enters the engine room and can hardely touch the leaking valve before the steam devours him, large blisters feeding on his flesh while the whistling valve cover his sceams. There is no distinguishing the man's agony from the machinery's cries, and the door is hurriedly sealed shut. The inhumane shrieks continue to resound through the ship for the rest of the trip.
802539: The least bad of your worst. The volunteer penetrates the engine room wrapped in layers of wet cloths as the crew ventilates the room by quickly opening and closing its door, avoiding the steam with damp armors of their own. The man manages to close the valve and the rest of the steam is evacuated in the same ridiculously plain manner. The immediate danger is avoided, and the crew wisely decides to avoid any more risk-taking and wait for the storm to end on its own.
802540: Don't you know when to stop? The sailor covers himself in damp cloths and enters the engine room, where the steam contaminates the wet protection with insufferable heat. He springs from the room covered in blisters, a monster of molten skin which howls agony beyond human comprehension, its outcry echoed by the tempest. The steam follows and burns all sailors within its grasp, taking delight in the stolen flesh until it finally recedes, replete thanks to the stubborness of the crew.
802541: Audacious! Abandoning the steam engines, the crew focuses its efforts on using all sails available on the ship. The sailors have may not have faced tempests this grand before, but they have crossed seas and braved oceans aboard all kinds of vessels, and navigation is in their blood. The wind is faced and the waves ignored and the steering wheel locked into place, allowing the ship to stay steady until the storm passes. Not the most natural solution for a steam ship, but a good display of skill.
802542: Reckless! Attempting to face the tempest without the ship's main power source is folly, and the crew cannot handle the safety sails as well as they imagined. They try to face the waves to break their momentum, but the ship's mishandling lets it drift and offers its flanks to the tempest. When the sun pierces the clouds, it reveals a spectacle of lacerated sails, flooded supplies, and disgruntled sailors.
802543: The storm passes. With the sails reefed to avoid damage, the sailors have only themselves to care about: they bury under the deck in wet bundles, shivering under the biting cold of the unremitting downpour. The endless wait is dispelled by a timid sun, and the expedition can finally resume.
802544: A negligible change of course. Letting the storm push your ship as it pleases upsets the most hot-headed sailors, but those with an actual brain upstairs appreciate the prudent approach. When the storm recedes, the ship's slight change of course takes a full week to be corrected - a decent trade-off for your safety.
802547: Little cohabitation can be found among believers and apostates. To ensure the diversity of your crew's skills, your sailors were recruited regardless of their origins or beliefs, and your lieutenants now wonder if this was a mistake. After weeks of lasting rainstorms, the most devout sailors raise their voice: this constant punishment is a sign of the divine, testifying to His obvious displeasure in the heresy onboard. Zealots speak of riot.
802548: Consult The Illiad on the matter
802549: Consult The Odyssey on the matter
802550: Consult the Norse Sagas on the matter
802551: Consult the Egyptian tales on the matter
802552: Consult an ancient romance on the matter
802553: Consult Skaldic poetry on the matter
802554: Convince the apostates to come back to the light
802555: Convince the zealots into accepting their differences
802556:
The Old Norse has much wisdom to share.
“Men brave and generous live the best lives, seldom will they sorrow; then there are fools, afraid of everything, who grumble instead of giving.”
Snorri's Edda is a gentle but firm reminder to your sailors that their grievances are shallow and foolish. No agreement is voiced that night, but all know that an understanding is born.
802557:
The Odyssey's wisdom seeps into your sailors' souls.
"For a friend with an understanding heart is worth no less than a brother."
Gathered around the first mate for an improvised reading session, the sailors can't ignore how the tale of friendship reminds them of their own adventures, of their own mistakes, of their own companions. Difference in faith is a detail. Their unity is what prevails.
802558:
Mythical tales give a lesson to your crew.
"Come then, let us give each other glorious presents, so that any of the Achaians or Trojans may say of us: 'These two fought each other in heart-consuming hate, then joined with each other in close friendship.'"
Hector's speech reminds your sailors of the values that bond them in this expedition: thrill, friendship, discovery, not anger nor fratricide over different beliefs. They sheepishly make up.
802559:
The epic poem puts your crew's petty fights in perspective.
"The battle continued from day to day; and all they who fell, and all the swords that lay on the field of battle, and all the shields, became stone."
The crew itself is petrified as it hangs onto the first mate's every word while he progresses through the poems of the Skáldskaparmál. The tale transports them to a time where pride had a greater value than faith, and their anger goes out.
802560:
Your sailors bond in their love of a great tale.
“For love will cure him that is sick, and rouse him that is in dumps; one that has loved, it will remember of it; one that has not, it will instruct."
The first mate closes his novel, leaving the crew to ponder over the fate of Daphnis and Chloe. The sailors, moved by their love, find themselves wiping tears over the story. The shared emotion gives them a common ground during which they can pretend their differences do not exist.
802561:
There's a mystifying wisdom in the Egyptian Book of the Dead.
Although no exact quote can be extracted from the detailed drawings, the translator's work in dissecting the Ptolemaic manuscript manages to build texts akin to the original meaning. Your sailors' trivial quarrels reveal their narrow-minded nature as the first mate unravels tales of fratricide and weighed souls. The tensions loosen as much as they can.
802562:
There is relief in promised forgiveness.
"For the Lord your God is gracious and compassionate. He will not turn his face from you if you return to him."
The priest's words are filled with his own altruism and make the promise ring true. The crew agrees, albeit awkwardly, to put aside their differences and engage in a calm exchange over their beliefs - the anger is quelled, but the heresy remains.
802563:
Your priest's ideals are far from peaceful.
"If your friend who is as your own soul entices you secretly, saying, 'Let us go and serve other gods,' your hand shall be first against him to put him to death!"
The menace embodies what the apostates criticise: a blind upholding of beliefs at the cost of your own humanity. The zealous priest is found hanged the next day - a warning to all who would chastise one's faith or lack of it.
802564:
Your diplomat finds the right words.
"God is a circle whose center is everywhere and circumference nowhere."
The quote is surprising coming from the woman of law, who manages to put aside her own beliefs to show respect for the zealots' faith. The crew listens intently and all agree that the expedition might be the occasion to discover and appreciate the beliefs of others, despite a sustained atmosphere of skepticism.
802565:
The diplomat finds no common ground with the zealots.
"When it is a question of money, everyone is of the same religion!"
The argument is as wrong as it is insulting. Does the man not think that sailors embarked on the expedition for more than their pay? His lack of respect rouses the anger of the zealots, drawing the attention away from the apostates. Nothing more than a shift in the target of their hatred.
802568: The ship's coffers have been emptied! Your purser knew these new recruits had a wicked air about them. As soon as the ship reached port and the sailors were allowed some rest, the three landsmen merged with the local crowd and disappeared and with them went weeks of pay. The theft was planned in every minute detail - your sailors have been robbed by professionals.
802572: The fleeing footprints are easily found. The tracks of the thieves' limping leader stand out in the dust. The grazing light of the setting sun highlights the path for your huntsmen and leads them away from the town and closer to its river, where tracks disappear in the water. The hills rise sharply on the other side.
802573: No tracks are found. The bustling harbour and the late evening insist on hiding the thieves' tracks. Your sailors are not skilled enough to pick up the faint trail inside the town itself, but they might have better luck around its outskirts.
802574: Look for a ford to cross on foot
802575: Create a raft to cross the river
802576: A safe passage! The crew's expertise shines as they rapidly spot a shallow part in the river and cross it without much inconvenience. They go up the sharp hill of the opposite bank and happen upon a vast enclosed field: a pen for horse breeding. A quick discussion with the owner confirms that the thieves stole several animals mere hours ago. The land beyond is barren and unfit for explorers on foot. Your crew needs horses.
802577: Your crew finds no guarantee of safe crossing. The sailors quickly get tired of the senseless search: the river's depth cannot be appraised by their untrained eyes, and each segment of the water seems both deep and shallow. The crew is too reluctant to try its luck, and abandons its search, disgruntled.
802580: The tamed horses easily catch up with your prey. Your hunters lasso the wild animals and break them before launching them through the barren plains. The blurry hot air parts to reveal the thieves' horses, whose speed is no match for wild ones. Your riders surround them and the menace of their number and drawn pistols hushes any resistance. The sailors, satisfied and avenged, retrieve their loot and entrust the scoundrels to the local law.
802581: Your sailors are not made to catch land animals. The hunt ends in failure, the most your crew saw of a wild horse being weathered tracks in the dry roads. Instead of leading your hunters to a herd, the tracks drive them to a run-down town of wooden buildings -several houses and a single saloon-, its lanterns brightening with the growing darkness. Night is well on its way and tracking the thieves seems almost impossible now.
802584: Avoid trouble and simply give up
802585: The locals agree to help. Your diplomat carefully brings the subject of thieves to a man of imposing authority, the sheriff in charge of the small town. The modus operandi is familiar to him: a local gang is famous for their sneaking around foreign businessmen, but he never would have imagined they'd be so bold as to rob a ship. If the robbery was today, he says, the thieves are sure to come and celebrate at the saloon tonight.
802586: Your crew is held responsible for the deserters' actions. Instead of probing around to get an idea of the runaways' reputation, your diplomat immediately asks about the thieves. The men are well-known in the worst way and the locals are shocked to hear your crew hosted them, regardless of the theft - the sailors are forced to leave when surrounded by stern-looking gunslingers. The track ends here. More than money, your sailors have lost morale.
802587: Wait on the town's balconies, ready for an ambush
802588: Wait at the saloon, ready for a fight
802589: A clean job. As soon as the thieves come into sight, your sailors stealthily lay their firearms on the rail guards of balconies and aim and fire in rapid succession. The shots resonate through the quiet town: one shot, one permanent sleeper. When the sound and smell of gunshots settle down, the sheriff salutes your crew's help in getting rid of local pests and ensures the sailors that their reputation will be made known through the West.
802590: Rout. Your sailors fire as soon as the gang comes into view, taking little time to aim and even less to observe their targets. The bullets graze past the thieves and upset their horses, who rear and jump before running away with their riders. A night drizzle starts falling and soon drowns their tracks. That's as far as the crew's efforts, notable but inefficient, can go.
802591: Honour and wages are retrieved.When the gang slams the saloon's doors open, the place is devoid of its usual chirpy atmosphere. Moon rays disclose the presence of your crew, sat on every possible chair and table and stair step and already reaching for their guns. The fight is brief. Your sailors submerge the thieves and drag them outside, roped and gagged, and salute the sheriff before heading back to the ship with the satisfaction of a job well done.
802592: Your crew is no match for the criminals. When the gang barges into the saloon, the sailors are still arguing over how to handle the fighting in such a closed space. The fight is short-lived. Your sailors lack the rough training and ability of their opponents and can barely fling insults at them, even less punches. The beaten crew is thrown outside and scampers away from the town - very aware of how lucky they are to still be alive.
802593: So much effort for such a meagre reward. Feeling the pressure of unseen stares, your crew avoids the shady town and backs away to the harbour city and their ship. Better to decide on your own to withdraw than to be forced to, the sailors tell themselves. Frustration nibbles their thoughts as they set sail.
802594: You can choose either to rent or buy a mount.
802597: The animals catch up with your prey in no time! In a flurry of dust and whinnying, the mounts assail the barren plains. The blurry hot air parts to reveal the thieves, perched atop horses already exhausted from their mishandling. Your riders surround them and the menace of their number and drawn pistols hushes any resistance. The sailors, satisfied and avenged, retrieve their loot and entrust the scoundrels to the local law.
802598: Your crew will make do on its own. The price for the withered mares reeks of scam and your sailors refuse to pay a single pound for the animals. Their observations might be influenced by the light weight of their purses.
802599: A safe passage! The raft is basic but sturdy, and it crosses the river without losing so much as a plank. The crew boards the opposite bank safely and climbs the hill rising right beyond it. On the other side, they happen upon a vast enclosed field: a pen for horse breeding. A quick discussion with the owner confirms that the thieves stole several animals mere hours ago. The land beyond is barren and unfit for explorers on foot. Your crew needs horses.
802600: The raft can't even float. Your sailors bind logs and dead branches together, binding them with sturdy knots but little knowledge of how to actually assemble the ropes. The raft's apparent stability tricks the builders into climbing onto it, and the raft swirls over the river, wobbling under the weight of sailors and the pressure of the current, before breaking and diving straight into the icy water. Few sailors can be rescued from the wreckage.
802603: Finally, tracks to follow! Amidst the numerous footprints left by your sailors, your best huntsmen manage to find the dotted lines left in the dust by the fleeing thieves. There's no mistaking the bent pattern of their limping leader. The prints waddle to the nearest river, where they fade in the water.
802604: Isn't this humiliation enough? Your crew keeps foraging through the outskirts of town, but they still cannot find any tracks.
802605: Your purser protests but the decision is final. Going after the thieves in a territory they seem to know by heart while the crew itself is in foreign territory? The risk will not be taken. As the ship sails away from the harbour and the villains it hosts, your sailors mourn the plundered funds.
802606: Your purser protests but the decision is final. Going after the thieves in a territory they seem to know by heart while the crew itself is in foreign territory? The risk will not be taken. As the ship sails away from the harbour and the villains it hosts, your sailors mourn the plundered funds.
802610: Your sailors face the mountain without a map. After a race from guide to guide through the depths of the mountain range, the crew finds itself devoid of chaperon: the guide supposed to take them on this last trip didn't show up at the agreed time. Forget what initial goal the exploration followed. Getting out of the snow-whipped peak is the only priority.
802611: Traverse the mountain on your own
802613: Your navigators make do without a guide. They take note of landmarks as they progress, relying on their compasses to follow a straight direction, staying put during the night despite the dwindling supplies. At long last they find a stream of melted snow and follow it downhill to the feet of the mountain. The crew survived, but it was a tough effort.
802614: A guide would have been helpful. Your sailors navigate the mountain paths to the best of their ability, which is not enough. The narrow roads disappear under the snow mist and they branch around the skeletal trees, spreading your crew across their ramifications. When the explorers reach a decent camping ground and count their numbers, five of them are missing.
802618: Go forward, leaving marks for the lost sailors to follow
802619: Go back, and look for the missing sailors
802620: The feet of the mountain, at last. The crew progresses step by step, testing the frozen snow for gaps and leaving piles of stones for the lost sailors to follow. Building the landmarks takes time but it helps avoiding any backtracking. The main group is soon joined by the missing sailors, disgruntled to have been left behind despite the crew's efforts at guiding them, and they reach the end of the mountain range in silence, unable to express their relief.
802621: The explorers get more lost with each passing day. They venture deep into the mountain and quickly abandon the idea of leaving marks for the lost sailors, too concerned for their own survival. The frost solidifies their clothes, steals their toes and rots their food.
802622: Follow a stream of melted snow running downhill
802623: Force your way through the mounds of powder snow
802624: Prioritise your supplies and look for food
802625: Your sailors manage to follow the stream to the mountain's feet. The stream flows in and out of the frozen ground, playing hide and seek with the desperate crew. They are not the only ones using the trickle as a guide: just before reaching the plains below the mountain, they meet with the missing sailors as they quell their burning thirst in the meagre snow stream. It's unclear which of the two teams is the most pitiful, but all are alive.
802626: Where did they come from? Where should they go? The melting snow splits into a web of entangled streams which buries under the ground and resurfaces without any apparent logic. The crew is taken by the illusion that the forest around them is flat and can no longer tell if they are climbing or descending. They split like the streams themselves, to each sailor their trickle, and like the streams not all of them find the feet of the mountain.
802627: The sailors draw strength from their last resources. They ignore the colossal distance they have to cross and focus on small milestones instead. Two steps to that tree. Three steps to that rock. The snow parts as they advance, drawing dark trenches which run across the pure white mantle and reach the feet of the mountain. The crew stumbles and falls in relief when they realize they made it out alive.
802628: The sailors are too weakened by the cold. They dig through the powder snow which collapses on them without revealing any safe path. Their endurance crippled by the frost, they abandon the task and try to focus on less demanding options.
802629: The crew extends its stay in the cold to gather supplies. Game is scarce and hunting takes time. However, the food makes for a decent meal and the smell of roasted hare fills the sailors' stomachs almost as well as the meat itself. The cooking fire's lights spreads through the forest at night and beckons the missing sailors. Reunited, the crew avoids talking about abandoning their companions and they leave the mountain in silence.
802630: Your hunters fall prey to the mountain. Animals' tracks sprinkle the fresh snow, but their owners are invisible, hidden in holes and burrows. The hunters are unused to such terrain. As they progress through the forest, discussing where snares could be the most efficient, the frozen ground suddenly breaks under them and a handful of sailors dives into a deep fault.
802631: The missing sailors are found, and with them an exit. The idea of losing their companions pushes the hunters to persevere. Broken twigs, brushed moss, mud splashes: everything is a hint. They follow the trail to a crossing and find the lost sailors, who welcome them heartily: they have found a beaten path which leads straight to the feet of the mountain! That they believed in the others and waited for them is a reward in and of itself.
802632: The fresh snow hides the dangers underneath. A powdery white covers everything in sight and the skies melt into the ground, hiding the horizon. The hunters advance on instinct, unable to look for hints of their previous passage. They find the missing sailors by encountering their fate: the frozen ground breaks under their weight. The thin crust of ice hid a fault! Three of the lost men are down there, and two hunters joined them.
802633: Pull the sailors from the fault, at the risk of falling
802637: The rescue comes at the price of their remaining strength. It takes ten sailors to get one man out of the fault: three to pull, six to hold and one to keep an eye on the trembling layer of ice. The snow weighs them down, pushing when they pull, hissing when they call out. When the last sailor is hauled from the rift, both rescuers and rescued are broken. They drag themselves downhill and manage to leave the clutch of the mountain.
802638: The ordeal is much bigger than your sailors. They launch ropes into the rift but the slippery walls of ice cannot be climbed. The rescuers attempt to haul the others up, and they plant their feet into the ground, pulling and pulling and panting, their physical reserves long drained by the cold. As they fall to their knees and break their nails on the frozen hemp, the rift cracks and the mountain opens its mouth wide. The swallowed crew is never seen again.
802639: Salvation at the price of their humanity. Ignoring the begging screams of their companions, the sailors make a large detour to avoid falling into the frozen rift. As they find a beaten path heading downhill, a sailor catches up to the group, panting: he admits to having thrown pickaxes and ropes down the fault. The crew congratulates him for his selflessness, and they pretend the deed was enough to ease their conscience.
802643: An overweight ship is easy prey for stormy waves. The oil merchants your crew met at the last harbour paid good money for their cargo to be stored aboard your ship, but the weight isn't really something your vessel can handle. At the first signs of tempest winds and cutting waves, the unusual ballast makes your ship heel furiously.
802644: Release the stern anchor to the sea floor
802645: Improvise a sea anchor on the surface of the water
802646: Safe. The cast-iron shank of the anchor plunges into the shifting waves with a large splash, the amount of chain being just right for it to take a good hold of the sea floor. The ship wobbles, washed by the waves and winds, but manages to stay put. The sailors simply wait for the storm to pass and hope the extra load will not cause any more problems.
802647: A miss - the crew should go hide in the lower decks. The anchor is released, its chain unravelling by itself more than it is controlled, and the large iron cross reaches the bottom with too much play to properly grip the sea floor. As it becomes apparent the anchor will not be of any help, the lieutenants order all to descend into the bottom of the swinging ship - but the oil merchants refuse to leave the apparent safety of their upper cabins.
802648: Take the time to present this solution as the best
802649: Drug them to avoid losing any more time
802650: The loss of time was necessary. Your lieutenants take the time to convince the merchants, detailing all available options one by one despite the increasingly high pressure from the waves and the rocking of the ship. Their stoicism more than their arguments convince the merchants of following orders, and they join the rest of the crew in the lower deck until the storm comes to pass.
802651: A loss of time.Pressed by the emergency of the situation and unable to get their thoughts in order, your lieutenants cannot properly convince the merchants. As they begin to lose their nerve, the ship swerves and slams into the shore. Whistling winds invade the perforated hull and water seeps in their wake.
802652: Repair the hole while the water is still pouring
802653: Move the ballast to lift the hole above sea level
802654: Your crew is used to repairs in poor conditions. Ignoring the swinging floor, the sailors focus on the hull, their legs deep into the pouring water. Drenched supplies float and sink around them as they plug the hole. The seal will not last long, but it should hold until the next harbour.
802655: Your crew's speed cannot match the water's. Overwhelmed by the current and unable to prioritise their tasks or even shape a plan of the repairs, the sailors quickly abandon the idea of patching up the hull. They flee to the upper deck and brace themselves as the ship crashes on the shore, ripped apart. The repairs last for weeks.
802656: The forced instability protects the ship. Your sailors huff and puff as they push the large sacks of basalt stones across the belly of the ship, progressively tipping the vessel's balance until its pierced flank leans away from the water. The ship is carefully led to the shore, where the crew can finally start repairs.
802657: A ludicrous plan. Your sailors wheeze and gasp as they try to pull the basalt sacks, but their efforts are not enough to budge the ballast into place. The ship remains steady, allowing more and more water in and sinking with the intrusion. Several sailors drown, trapped between the deck's roof and the swirling currents, and their bodies cannot be evacuated before the storm calms down.
802658: Safe and drunk. The merchants accept the liquid courage and drink its laced contents, falling asleep before they can finish their bottle. They're dragged to the lower deck with the rest of the crew and what supplies the sailors could carry, their combined weight counterbalancing the pounding of the waves. The storm soon calms down and leaves the crew to deal with the hangover of their passengers.
802659: Too weak. The drinks your sailors offer to the merchants in an attempt to soothe their anger are far too poorly made to have any kind of impact on them. As they continue to struggle against your crew, a vivid growl resonates in the ship: it came too close to shore, and the reefs pierced your hull! Water starts to pour in the lower decks.
802660: The sea anchor works properly. Your sailors bind planks with a docking line and lest the makeshift anchor with a ripped sail, before letting the construction drop into the waves. It sips the water in its cloth, bobbing with the sea, pulling against the water to increase its drag. Your ship gains enough stability to keep its broadside away from the waves and the crew, relieved, can wait for the storm to pass.
802661: The sea anchor sinks as soon as it touches the water. The sailors tack together extra sails to try and assemble a sea anchor, but the ballooning cloths snap as soon as they're thrown into the waves. As the ship is pushed towards the shore the backwash gets more and more ample, until a rogue wave of ludicrous proportions rises above the sea. Your merchant passengers beg your crew to save them!
802664: Throw the oil cargo overboard to calm the seas
802665: Fearless. Despite the battering gale and clobbering currents, your crew manages to keep the ship straight and face the rogue wave head on. The wave crashes into your vessel with all its rage and natural power, but the straight prow cuts its fury in two and the ship avoids most of the damage - a rock among the waters. When the storm calms down, your crew focuses on the repairs and considers how exceptional their survival was.
802666: Too audacious. The gusts of wind fill your sails and the frantic currents pull your hull, and your crew is way too untrained to keep their reins over the ship. Entailed by the sea's passion, the ship leaps and falls, dancing until the shore catches it and stops its mad waltz. The vessel's carcass stays still, water and bodies flowing from its bent silhouette.
802669: The water's anger dies out! Moving the merchants aside with ease and dismissing their plea, your sailors heave the oil barrels over the railings and let their contents spill around the ship. The oil hugs the water and rolls over the waves, dissolving the wind's grip and slowing the water's movement. The threat of the waves is no more, but the merchants' trust and cargo were lost in the process.
802670: Their greed overcomes your strength. The sailors try to reason, then to force the merchants into giving up their precious oil, but your crew is weak in both body and spirit while the merchants have built their fortunes on hard-headedness. Long after the ship has been hit, crushed, and stranded, the merchants's cadavers are found lying on the shore's pebbles, still clutching their barrels of cargo.
802673: The local authorities are looking for the refugee you have taken in. A man in rags offers you his services in a harbour, arguing that he'd do any odd job for food and a chance at joining your crew. Unlike other temporary hires, he grows onto your sailors, filling in wherever there is work, catching onto the ship's spirit and disputing debates over the expedition's course. His skills testify to a life beyond that of a common sailor, but your crew respects his secrecy. As your ship leaves the harbour, a patrolling warship stops it: they are looking for a political dissident and the description matches your new recruit.
802676: "Is it a fight you are looking for?"
802678: "Here is the man you are looking for."
802679: Your crew presents a coherent lie. Have anyone anywhere seen anybody? They inspect the picture of the runaway, speculate on hiding places, rummage through the cargo while the refugee buries under the supplies, unseen. The pretence of dedication convinces the authorities, who leave after a warm acknowledgement of their efforts. When the harbour is out of sight, the runaway emerges with a grin worth all thanks. A new recruit for your expedition!
802680: Your crew's deceit is silly at best. The lieutenants argue that they just arrived into port and couldn't possibly have had any contact with the population yet, but the warship obviously saw your vessel dock at the harbour. Their suspicions roused, they ask you to lower a footbridge for an inspection of the ship.
802681: Hide the man and allow them onboard
802682: Threaten to fire your cannons at their ship
802683: No better places to hide than the ones you know by heart. Your sailors stash the fugitive into the belly of the ship, a bundle of rags buried between crates of supplies and sacks of food. A perfect camouflage. The patrolling guards soon abandon their inspection and let your ship leave after taking note of its name. To avoid future inspections, the runaway chooses to leave at the next island.
802684: The fugitive is more lost than the guards. Your sailors shove him in the lower deck and urge him to hide without any form of guidance or advice. When the patrol guards descend into the ship, they find the runaway rummaging through the crates, still looking for a place to hide. They immediately seize him.
802685: Enough complying already - threaten them to leave or else!
802686: Enough errors already - let them take the man
802687: Your threat works despite the situation. The sailors surround the guards in silence, stepping between them and the runaway, forcing the intruders to the upper deck and off the ship. Your vessel leaves before they can call reinforcements and the fugitive is dropped at the first harbour, for fear of retaliation. The separation is hurried and leaves a sour aftertaste. At least, with luck, he'll be safe.
802688: There's no threatening these men. Your sailors try to step between them and the runaway, but the lump of scrawny arms and pouting faces is far from intimidating. They are shoved away and what few sailors try to resist are hauled along with the fugitive and taken to suffer his fate: death by hanging.
802689: Your crew offers little resistance. They part before the patrol as it advances to seize the runaway. The dissident starts to thank the sailors for their efforts, but a slap shuts him up and he is collared before being dragged away. Your crew never managed to create the safe haven he deserved. They watch the warship disappear along the coast, trying to refrain from imagining the fate of their friend.
802690: Your firepower is impressive indeed. The sailors line all hatches with cannons and light their fuses in the same movement, aiming the dark mouths at the patrolling warship. The patrol captain hurriedly orders his own crew to hurtle away from the crazy fools. The cannonade salutes their departure. The fugitive is extremely thankful and leave your crew at the next island with a warm goodbye.
802691: An empty threat. Lying about your itinerary was more credible than pretending your ship can muster any form of naval power. Eyeing your sailors as they struggle to deploy and load the cannons, the patrol captain orders his men to get ready to board your ship. Your crew is suspicious enough for him.
802692: They don't board you. You board them!
802693: Let them board the ship and take the man
802694: The assault is abrupt and wicked. For an agonizing moment of hesitation none seems to prevail, until your sailors manage to get the upper hand and slaughter the warship's crew. Your vessel flees the harbour and drops the fugitive at the next safe island, aware they have made enemies out of legal authorities for the sake of one good man.
802695: The fight is routine for your opponents. Your crew boards the warship with nothing more than their confidence, and their sluggish skills crash against the overwhelming discipline of the patrol guards. The runaway stands up to help your sailors, screaming to get the guards' attention, and is instantly shot. His death marks the end of the fight. Your ship is exiled before the crew can mourn their dead.
802696: The patrol cowers away from your ship. Of course they are not looking for a fight, not with a vessel looking as overpowered as yours! It might have been their swift deployment of cannons or the absolute stoicism with which your sailors warned the patrol - either way, your presence and menace is overwhelming. Your ship is free to leave the harbour, its new recruit already toasting to his freedom and the crew gladly following him.
802697: The patrol is not impressed by your ship's armament. Your crew flings slurs at the inspection warship and scatters through the ship, deploying unsteady cannons, bumping against closed hatches and very audibly cursing their lack of ammunitions. Trying to refrain his laughter as his own crew deploys brand new ordnance rifles, the patrol captain asks your sailors to demonstrate how they intend to overpower him.
802700: It takes one accurate shot to demonstrate power. Giving up on shooting all cannons, your sailors focus on firing the single best shot of their lives. The cannonball flies past the warship's railings and crushes their mainmast, sending wood and metal to rain on the patrol guards and giving your ship the window of time necessary to flee. The fugitive leaves your crew at the next island, grateful but unwilling to aggravate your feud with the local authorities.
802701: Poor decision. Following their display of clumsy preparation, your sailors try to attack using the artillery they were insulting a second before. The cannons rear under their mishandling and fire at the ship itself, piercing hole after hole in the hull and hurling sailors into the sea. The patrol faces no resistance when they come onboard, pluck the fugitive, and leave the devastated vessel.
802702: Your crew offers little resistance. They part before the patrol as it advances to seize the runaway. The dissident starts to thank the sailors for their efforts, but a slap shuts him up and he is collared before being dragged away. Your crew never managed to create the safe haven he deserved. They watch the warship disappear along the coast, trying to refrain from imagining the fate of their friend.
802703: The fugitive holds his breath as you prepare the bribe.
802706: A smooth operation. The patrol pockets your goods with twisted smiles, your payment surpassing the rewards promised for the capture of the runaway. As they clear the way and your ship passes by them, your new recruit waves to the guards and curtsies before wishing them a great day. Yes, your crew is going to like him.
802707: Your offer is far from enough. The patrolling guards must have been promised a great reward for the capture of the fugitive. Taking your attempt as an effort to bribe them and highly suspicious behaviour, they lower footbridges and open cannon hatches, ready to board your ship.
802708: Your sailors hand over the runaway. The refugee is dejected but keeps his emotions in check, letting the patrolling guards chain him while looking straight at your crew. His look is avoided. The patrol rewards the sailors with bags of supplies, a miserable trade for the life of a good man and the shame of your crew.
802711: Castaways request your help, but where could they be? Shark-baiting is a common distraction for your sailors. Their latest catch provided much more entertainment than expected: in its belly was a bottle and in the bottle were three sheets of paper, each a copy of the same message in different languages. Piecing together the documents to make up for their weathered content, the crew can make out a call for help and a latitude, but nothing more.
802712: Examine the entrails of the shark for clues
802713: Map the islands matching the partial coordinates
802714: There's no time to spare for such things
802715: The stomach of the shark reveals where it's been. Glittering corals, exotic scales, characteristic fish bones. Your doctors finish their inspection of the shark's entrails and confirm the destination: to the Southern coral barriers! When the ship reaches the correct latitude, several islands litter the horizon. The crew hesitates to come closer. The water is shallower than usual and filled with sharp coral reefs.
802718: Navigate closer to the islands and their reefs
802719: Stay away and have the look-out search for castaways
802720: Your ship avoids the deadly reefs and finds the castaways! The vessel groans as it swims through the limpid waters, the deepest corals reflecting its shadow as it avoids them. It takes a short while to find the castaways, entrenched among the dunes of a secluded beach and sprouting from it with squeals of joy and disbelief. Their captain offers his unalienable loyalty and your crew gladly welcomes the newcomers.
802721: The ship cannot pass the underwater barrier. Despite your navigator's efforts, the ship bumps against the coral reef - the manoeuvre is too complex and too risky for her. The crew is forced to turn its back to the paradisiacal islands. Whether the castaways were real, whether they were indeed stranded here, they will never know.
802722: Found them! Your look-out shows their brilliance when they spot the thin smoke line of a campfire in the distance. A dinghy is sent to retrieve the castaways and comes back filled to the brim with men in overgrown beards, torn clothes, and awed faces. Their captain pledges himself to your crew and, once shaved and washed, the castaways prove themselves to be excellent sailors and even better companions.
802723: The look-out draws a blank. Scanning the islands from afar is a difficult exercise, made even harder by the lack of experience. The crew soon realizes that it will never find anyone from such a distance. Reluctant to risk the ship's integrity over the mere possibility of the castaways' existence, your sailors choose to leave and forget.
802724: The homemade autopsy is a mess. The shark's entrails are cut along with their contents and spilled over the deck is a nauseous mass of gore and artefacts of unknown origin. The doctor cannot make sense of the anarchy he created.
802725: Interpret the patterns in the shark's entrails
802727: Relentless faith guides the most deserving. In the spilled gut of the shark, your navigators see the shapes of islands, your doctors see the patterns of life forms, your boatswain sees the promise of rewards. Driven by an inner force beyond simple greed, the crew sails past coral reefs and insidious currents and finds the island on which the castaways had been waiting for rescue. Their relief is glorious and their captain promises to serve your crew!
802728: There is nothing to find but deceit. Your cooper burns sage among the remains of the shark and sniffs the lumpy smoke. If forces do talk to him, they might have been beyond what he could handle: he suddenly pounces on the closest sailor, crushing her throat between his hands. Three more fall before his frenzy drives him overboard with an otherworldly scream. The castaways are cursed and the sailors mourn their comrades for the rest of the trip.
802729: Shark, bottle and messages are thrown overboard. Several sailors protest against the rash decision and would have preferred to exhaust all options before giving up, or at least keep the messages to share them at the next harbour. The imagined blame and grief of the castaways haunt them for a while.
802730: The search defines a searchable area. Many islands match the latitude but much less could be mapped on an actual shipping route. By deducing where the castaways' ship might have gone, your navigators identify a handful of islands which could host the castaway. After two weeks of smooth sailing, your ship reaches the area: a necklace of islands linked by strands of deadly coral reef.
802731: Your navigator is overwhelmed by the mass of possibilities. Unable to find a proper searching method and define a list of reasonable proportions, they abandon their task and admit the crew might as well try to work out the contents of the entrails. It is said as a joke, however, some sailors consider the idea.
802732: The bottle and its messages are thrown back into the sea. The crew's regrets drift away with the bottle and the castaways are soon forgotten.
802735: Your chaplain is going overboard with his preaching. Blaming the expedition's mishaps and hazards on the supposed heresy of the ship's officers, the man of faith manages to rouse the gradual distrust and anger of the sailors. His preaching is now part of the crew's daily routine. His words find echo in the mouths of the sailors, and your lieutenants can see their authority slipping away.
802736: Demonstrate that his doubts are fuelled by a mental illness
802737: Discredit him in a direct confrontation
802738: Simply punish him without taking measures against his ideas
802739: The man of faith belongs to an asylum. Your doctor interrupts the chaplain's daily sermon and accuses him of megalomania, listing the traits of the madness: desire for attention, desire for control, desire to rouse the paranoia of others in order to match one's own. The portrait is a perfect depiction of the chaplain, and, despite their former affection for the man, the sailors agree that he should be sedated with laudanum for the rest of the trip.
802740: The doctor only proves his own paranoia. Your doctor interrupts the chaplain's daily sermon with a loud declaration, stating that the man of faith is, in fact, a soul tormented by a mental illness. With all eyes on him, your doctor utters a list of personal opinions rather than medical facts, and the chaplain welcomes his doubts with benevolence. His influence flourishes and your lieutenants have to make do with him for the rest of the trip.
802741: Your diplomat has a greater way with words. She silently enters the lower deck during the chaplain's daily preaching and waits in a corner of a room. When the man of faith finally loses his nerve and asks her what she wants, she lists two hours worth of the chaplain's arguments and, without pause, offers counterpoints for each of them. The humiliation is magnificent and the chaplain's babbling defence convinces the crew of his puerility. They lose interest.
802742: Your diplomat was not ready to face the chaplain. She confronts the preacher before the crew and flaunts her interpretation of the chaplain's mistakes, stating how wrong he is without taking into account the weeks of argument he had built with his followers. Her diatribe convinces none but herself, and the chaplain simply remarks that her anger is proof of his being right. Your lieutenants have to make do with his whims for the rest of the trip.
802743: Not the most diplomatic solution, but it works. Trusted sailors interrupt the chaplain during his daily preaching and drag him to the upper deck, where your first mate welcomes the man of faith with a devoted flogging. The display of violence mostly proves the preacher's point, but the menace of the officers' ire is greater than the crew's distrust in them. The trip resumes in a climate of tension.
802746: It's a pirate ship!The crew thought them extinct, but reality proves them wrong: a torn black flag bearing skull and bones flaps against the weather-worn mast of the approaching ship. The spectral silhouettes of starved men pile up against its rail guards, eager to feed on their prey.
802747: Release an anchor to pivot and face the attacking ship
802748: Let them come, rouse the spirit of the crew with a speech
802749: These scoundrels will see what true sailors look like! In a demonstration of their tactical flair, your crew works to release the starboard anchor. The weighed cross dives into the sea, finds a sturdy ledge, and commands the ship's movement. Your vessel jumps and drifts to the side - face to face with the pirates.
802750: The manoeuvre is a mess. There is a wide difference between the intent and the result. What tactical advantage your crew thought they could gain over the pirates is lost as soon as the anchor enters the water, slowing the ship down and turning it into a perfect target for its attackers.
802753: Flawless victory. The volley of cannonballs demolishes the pirate ship's flanks, each projectile aimed at the most mould-ridden parts of the wood. The antique vessel collapses on itself and your sailors have but to watch the pirates drown then loot the flotsam at will.
802754: Was this aimed at the pirates or the actual sky? Your cannonballs fly way over the pirate ship and allow the scoundrels to react to your sudden manoeuvre. The tide of the battle shifts in their favour again as grappling hooks catch your ship and lock it into place.
802757: Today is not the day you are vanquished by pirates. The attackers barely set foot on deck that your sailors launch their assault, a coordinated charge grinded into perfection by years of practice. Still, the pirates resist to the best of their ability, and their desperate foray costs the lives of a few good men.
802758: Panic. Your sailors lose their nerve and cannot handle the very thought of being boarded - they abandon their posts and weapons and beg for a mercy that is not given. The pirates, at least as frantic as their victims, slaughter several crew members before noticing their surrender. They plunder your supplies and scurry away.
802759: A refusal to fight. Bound by their code of honour, the pirates spurn the idea of killing any of the surrendering sailors and help themselves to your supplies. The shabby scoundrels celebrate their meagre plunder with glee and leave your crew riddled with pity for their attackers.
802760: The pirates didn't expect such a crafty attack. Instead of using the cannons, your sailors prepare explosives akin to those used in trench wars: a bottle filled with powder, hemp for the fuse, nails for the visual. The grenades spit their fire into the enemies' ship and terrify the pirates, who have never seen such techniques before. The tattered attackers summon your crew's pity, who lets them leave in exchange of a symbolic fee.
802761: Shouldn't your sailors focus on what they actually know? The crew improvises grenades based on hearsay of military tales, pouring powder and rusty metal into bags of moist hemp - unstable bombs which explode as soon as their fuse is lit. The sailors don't even have the time to count their victims: the pirates use the mayhem as a diversion, and they board your ship!
802762: Insist on fighting and steer the ship to face them
802764: Nice rectification. Fighting against the pulling anchor and the pushing current, your helmsman manages to stir the ship to the side and makes it face the pirates' vessel. This sequence of surprising movements gives your crew a small window of action before the pirates can react.
802765: Too hasty. Your helmsman is used to conventional manoeuvres only, and steering the ship while its anchor is still grazing the sea floor is beyond his nautical comprehension. The entire ship shakes and swirls, drifting over the waves in a violent jump which sends it crashing into the pirate ship. The scoundrels board you!
802768: Send the pirates down to the depths! First their mainmast, then their sails, then the deck itself: the pirate ship is bombarded in a relentless yet precise manner. Soon the pirates' corpses litter the sea, and your crew is free to fish their well-deserved rewards from the carcass of the pirate ship.
802769: Your crew is not up to the challenge. The first volley of cannonballs glides over the pirate ship and, quite remarkably, manages to miss the ship, its sails, and its masts. The attackers retaliate with their own cannons and the sea becomes a stage for your explosive exchanges. When the smoke clears, both ships are ruined and the pirates scamper away. Your crew celebrates their victory while trying to ignore the extensive damage.
802770: A present for Davy Jones, and booty for your crew. Your sailors are fighters by nature, and the ramshackle pirate crew is no match for them. What few scoundrels oppose the assault are sent to greet the fishes and the others are forced to surrender - your crew plunders their ship but find little loot on the decrepit vessel. It is pity more than mercy that makes them spare the pirates.
802771: There's no denying your crew's lack of strength. The sailors throw themselves at the pirates with a noticeable will to fight but hardly enough skill to fulfil their dreams of domination. The scrawny pirates beat the crew and leave, slightly less bruised and weary than their victims but too drained and wounded to linger on your ship.
802772: Fight till the decimation of either crew
802774: An underwhelming victory. Yes, your crew manages to gain the upper hand over the pirates and displays decent self-control and fighting skill, but the pirates are far from their image of wondrous sea fighters. They are weak. The skeletal attackers scatter as your sailors crush them, and your broken deck is littered with scrawny corpses. The repairs take a lesser toll on morale than the gnawing pity your crew feels for the scoundrels.
802775: Your sailors' desperation is no match for the pirates'. The attackers pour from the carcass of their ship, oblivious to the large faults in the wood, flowing like blood from a wound. They wash over your sailors, who scatter in their current, unable to oppose resistance and too weak to even consider it. When the wave of pirates recedes, your deck is covered in fragments of both ship and men.
802776: This should have been done much earlier. Your weapons are dropped just in time for the pirates to stop their assault. They spare the crew in exchange for a decent quantity of loot - however, their mercy will never give back the men lost to your hazardous manoeuvres and their outstanding failure.
802777: A refusal to fight. Bound by their code of honour, the pirates spurn the idea of killing any of the surrendering sailors and help themselves to your supplies. The shabby scoundrels celebrate their meagre plunder with glee and leave your crew riddled with pity for their attackers.
802778: There is faith in the upcoming victory. Your acting lieutenant climbs the rail guard and points his gun at the skies, defying the heavens themselves. I am weak, vulnerable, he says, like well-born men are - but while my body is feeble my heart is that of a captain, and your captain no less. And like you sailors I will fight, and I will fight to the death, and I will continue to fight after this death, for not a single pirate will lay a single finger on our ship, in this life or in the next!
802779: There's no spirit nor courage to be roused. Your crew barely reacts to your lieutenant's speech, hypnotized by the approaching pirate ship, entranced by their terror. The attackers board the ship and everything is both too fast and too slow: the massacre of the resisting sailors, the looting, the pirates' departure. When the crew regains its senses, they realize the price of their cowardice.
802782: A fantastic charge. Led by the acting lieutenant, your sailors hurtle down the boarding bridges and storm the pirate ship, leaving a trail of mangled scoundrels in their wake. The black flag is torn from its mast and the pirate booty is plundered. Taken by a sudden generosity, your crew lets the survivors scurry away with their wreck of a vessel. They might be the last pirates alive.
802783: Your sailors' strength is mental only. They lack both the skill and speed required for a quick take-down of the boarded ship, and allow the pirates to regroup behind makeshift barricades of crates and sacks of goods.
802784: Take cover and shoot from a distance
802786: The pirate ship is a playground for your crew. They avoid the shots of the scoundrels with ease and take cover, burying behind overthrown barrels of rum and taking down the pirates, accurate shot by accurate shot. When not a single enemy is left standing, your ship recovers its crew and leaves - victorious, but drenched in the smell of alcohol and gunpowder.
802787: Your crew is ill-prepared for this challenge. The sailors run around in circles, unable to settle on a good cover while the pirates shoot at will, taking them down with ease. The remaining members of your crew are spared in exchange of their cargo, and your expedition takes a toll from this loss.
802788: A manifestation of their true skill. Despite its initial fumbling, your crew manages to reach the pirates' covers and forces its way through the barricades, overpowering the scoundrels in a matter of minutes. Not a single pirate is left standing, and as few sailors as possible suffered the same fate. It was the best they could do.
802789: Stubbornness will not trigger miracles. Still proving how unskilled and weak they are, your sailors crash upon the pirates' barricade like foam upon the shore, and the gunshots scatter them across the deck. The pirates meet no resistance when they raid your ship, and the survivors shamelessly thank their attackers for taking nothing more than cargo.
802790: Flawless victory. The volley of cannonballs demolishes the pirate ship's flanks, each projectile aimed at the most mould-ridden parts of the wood. The antique vessel collapses on itself and your sailors have but to watch the pirates drown then loot the flotsam at will.
802792: Was this aimed at the pirates or the actual sky? Your cannonballs fly way over the pirate ship and allow the scoundrels to react to your bold, but uncontrolled manoeuvre. The tide of the battle shifts in their favour as grappling hooks catch your ship and lock it into place.
802795: A refusal to fight. Bound by their code of honour, the pirates spurn the idea of killing any of the surrendering sailors and help themselves to your supplies. The shabby scoundrels celebrate their meagre plunder with glee and leave your crew riddled with pity for their attackers.
802796: Today is not the day you are vanquished by pirates. The attackers barely set foot on deck that your sailors launch their assault, a coordinated charge grinded into perfection by years of practice. Still, the pirates resist to the best of their ability, and their desperate foray costs the lives of a few good men.
802797: Disaster. The courage of your sailors is not matched by their force, and the pirates wash through them like a wave through sand. When the attackers finally decide that culling your crew is not worth their time, the remaining sailors do not dare retaliate and simply stand their ground, keeping watch on their wrecked ship and devastated pride.
802800: Behind bars! The prolonged stay of your ship in this harbour is not a willed one. Obscure laws were breached and your whole crew was arrested under the pretence that borders, whose nature remains unknown, were not respected. Heavily armed foreigners lead your crew through the sinuous roads of their city and into the local jail, and after passing by a row of freshly hanged criminals, the sailors are locked up. Only two guards keep watch, their heads bobbing with fatigue. Are they underestimating your crew?
802803: Prepare your defence for the incoming trial
802804: Two guards are not enough to resist your science. The doctor brings out a sachet of vials and packets and produces leathery pouches filled with white powders, some matte, some glittering like sugar. He mixes a bit of this one and a bit of that one, gauging measures with the eye of the seasoned practitioner, then calls to the guards. When the unsuspecting wardens are close enough, the doctor blows the mixture in their face. The men drop dead!
802805: The doctor showcases his ignorance. He produces a pouch of arsenic before calling the guards. When the jailers are close enough, the doctor is ready to blow the powder in their face - however, his lack of knowledge of the poison's properties backfires: the soft inhalation of the doctor is enough to bring the highly volatile poison to his lips, and he leaps back, coughing and wheezing. The guards immediately understand this was attempted murder.
802806: Disguise as guards and escort the rest of the crew
802807: Avoid drawing any attention and sneak outside
802808: The escape is flawless. Two of your sailors don the guards' uniforms and drag the rest of the chained crew through the prison. When they are stopped at the exit, they mimic the local accent, briefly explain the liberation, and kick one of the chained sailors for good measure. The legitimate wardens buy the lie! It takes an even greater effort to refrain from laughing before reaching the ship and leaving the port.
802809: An attempt way beyond their ability. Two sailors put on the guards' uniforms and lead the crew through the prison, until legitimate guards stop them and enquire about the strange cortege. The disguised men's fidgety attitude and suspiciously foreign accent is enough to convince the wardens to check their original cell: the bodies are found and with them comes the heavy charge of murder. The following day, the trial is held.
802812: Offer to pay a fine, however high it might be
802813: Pretend these actions were a demand from the higher-ups and have the crew repudiate Her Majesty
802817: The price is high, but fair. Most of the expedition's budget is squandered in the brutal fine and if the crew is cleared of their charges, they find themselves forced to ration their supplies for the rest of the trip. The doctor and his accursed ideas are blamed and the man is turned into a scapegoat: his rations are regularly stolen, damaging his health and abilities, and, worse, the crew blatantly avoids his treatments.
802818: Who would accept such a meager payment? Murder is not a subject to be triffled with and the foreign court makes its opinion clear: your crew will pay in the hardest way possible. To show that they value life more than your sailors, the judges impose a non-lethal punishment and insist on this point, devising a program of forced labour and precise observation to make sure the sailors suffer as much as possible without dying. Months of hell follow before the crew can leave.
802819: That lie is believable, but it doesn't erase your crew's crimes. The foreign judges put aside any idea of death sentence and focus on finding a punishment befitting the crime: the crew is arranged into a procession and made to cross the city in chains, while chanting the ill-will of their Queen. Their patriotism tainted, the sailors never dare to pronounce her name again.
802820: Who would believe such an obvious lie? Why would their Queen ask for such a menial task as poisoning oversea guards? To match the crime, the crew's lieutenants are forced to drink hemlock solutions and trapped in a single cell with the rest of the crew. The lieutenants gag and wheeze for days of agony, their skin puffing and their muscles stiffening in impossible positions until their breathing itself is locked into place. Only then are the sailors allowed to leave.
802821: The perfect crime! Despite their numbers, your sailors manage to sneak through the prison and into the streets, where they become shadows under the moonless night. Led by your most competent hunters, they creep through back alleys and backyards until the obscurity delivers them below their ship. Feeling like the protagonists of an adventure novel and revelling in the sentiment, they leave the harbour in the gliding vessel - all lights off and no sound made.

The next morning, they are judged not for their meager trespassing, but for actual murder.
